A former Japanese school principal, Yuhei Takashima, has been arrested and charged with paying for sex with over 12,000 women, including some girls as young as 14, in the Philippines over a quarter of a century. Police seized 147,600 photos taken by Takashima, which included explicit images of underage girls, and alleged that he photographed and produced obscene acts in a hotel room in Manila. Takashima, now 64, claimed he started paying for sex due to financial necessity after leaving his job at a Japanese school in Manila in 1988. His arrest follows an investigation that began in 2013.

A Brazilian online football store claims to have sold next season's Chelsea kit with Gareth Bale's name on the back, which was previously published on the website. However, the kit features the sponsor "Yokohama" instead of Adidas. Additionally, the website sells three other Chelsea kits with the same design, but without the Adidas emblem. One of these kits features the number "Bale 9" on the back, sparking speculation about Bale's potential return to Chelsea. Meanwhile, another kit is available for purchase with Drogba's name on the back, although his current contract situation remains uncertain.

Clarence Taylor, 44, faked his own kidnapping by duct-taping his mouth and tying himself to a tree in Akron, Ohio, claiming it was a "bizarre" act. His 45-year-old girlfriend reported him missing on November 1, and while she was on the phone with investigators, her boyfriend received a call from another friend who said he had found him tied to a tree with zip ties. The unidentified man then led police to Taylor, who was still bound to the tree. Taylor later claimed he had stolen $2,500 from his girlfriend and was being held captive. Police charged Taylor with a first-degree misdemeanor charge of falsification due to the lack of evidence.

A satirical new video from the Make it Fair Project promotes gender equality by highlighting the disproportionate presence of men in influential industries such as Hollywood, government, and Fortune 500 companies. The video features an ensemble of actresses, including Rita Wilson, who appears alongside other notable stars like Meryl Streep's daughter Mamie Gummer, to discuss the issue of gender inequality. The video presents statistics showing that men hold 70-95% of key positions in these industries, and that men pay women significantly less than themselves. The actresses emphasize that "it's only fair" that men should have equal opportunities and pay, and that show business is not the only place where gender inequality persists.

Researchers suggest that a warming climate around 1.4 million years ago enabled the spread of distant human ancestors, the hominins, from Africa into Spain, where they eventually spread across Europe. Climate change impacted human migration, allowing them to move to new regions. An ancient human ancestor known as 'Nutcracker Man' lived on a diet of tiger nuts, worms, and grasshoppers, which may explain why the related species, Paranthropus boisei, had distinctive powerful jaws and large, flat molar teeth. The warming climate allowed these early hominins to inhabit the region, where they were supported by simple Oldowan tools.

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL running back, is suspected of killing his cellmate, Damion Soward, a 37-year-old inmate serving a life sentence for first-degree murder in Central California prison. Phillips, who was jailed in 2005 for choking his girlfriend and driving into three teenagers, is suspected of killing Soward, who was found dead in his cell on Saturday. Phillips was previously known as one of the nation's top college football players at Nebraska before being released in 1997 due to disciplinary issues. A second inmate at the prison is also suspected of killing Soward, while Phillips' lawyer has not been announced.

Liverpool's FA Cup semi-final defeat has put the club under scrutiny and guaranteed this campaign will be judged a failure. After a wretched day against Aston Villa, they are clearly some way from realising their ambition of becoming Champions League regulars. Manager Brendan Rodgers must provide the right answers come August to salvage the situation. Despite having a talented squad, Liverpool struggled to find form, particularly in front of goal, and ultimately crashed out of the competition in a 2-1 defeat to Aston Villa.

Google Maps combines with Pac-Man game, allowing users to play a virtual version of the classic arcade game in real-time. The feature, which was released as part of a larger April Fools' Day prank, allows users to navigate through iconic landmarks like Times Square and the Champs Elysees. Users can play the game by simply clicking on the Pac-Man icon on their Google Maps app.

Rangers boss Stuart McCall has been reassured that removing the club from the London Stock Exchange will not impact his team's promotion push. The club was de-listed from the AIM after interim chairman Paul Murray blamed the decision on the previous board, but McCall claims the new regime is considering switching to the ISDX market. Rangers welcomed newly-crowned Scottish Championship winners Hearts to Ibrox on Sunday, despite the potential financial implications of paying £500,000 to Newcastle United if they win promotion. McCall has expressed confidence in the club's ability to overcome the setback and focus on the upcoming match against Hearts.

A Canadian company, Vox Populi, is using the ".sucks" domain name to extract exorbitant sums from celebrities and companies looking to protect their reputations. The US body that regulates internet addresses is cracking down on the company, which has already begun selling purchased names, including Youtube.sucks, Bing.sucks, and others, to celebrities and brands. Vox Populi's CEO claims the domain is meant to provide a "destination for companies to interact with their critics." However, the advisory body sees this as a coercive scheme, warning that the threat of opening a ".sucks" site to the average consumer may be used to extort money.

Edinson Cavani's Champions League performance against Barcelona may have put to bed any chance of him joining Manchester United, as he fell flat on his face during a limp display for Paris Saint-Germain. Cavani has struggled to impress this season, despite being linked with a transfer to Manchester United. His disappointing display against Barcelona may have also raised concerns among Manchester United, who have been keeping a close eye on him due to his past performances. Cavani's lack of form in Ligue 1, where he was nearly unplayable before joining PSG, may also make him less attractive to Manchester United. With Cavani wanting to stay at PSG until the end of his contract, there is little hope of him leaving the French club anytime soon.

Sunderland's survival bid is still alive and well despite being in 15th place with 29 points, thanks to a strong performance against Newcastle. Even Sunderland are a bad weekend away from falling into the relegation zone. Hull, meanwhile, are in a precarious position in 17th with seven games remaining, while Leicester are just two points behind in 20th with 22 points. With five fixtures between Sunderland and Leicester, plus two more against other teams in the bottom six, the battle for Premier League survival is heating up.

Karim Benzema, a Real Madrid forward, showcased his rapping skills by posting a video of himself singing along to Tupac's "Check Out Time" while driving his Bugatti Veyron. The French striker also sang along to Tupac's "All Eyez on Me", which might be a better fit for his abilities. Benzema aims to add to his goal tally of 20 goals in all competitions this season. He believes his success with Real Madrid can help him secure the Ballon d'Or award. Benzema's teammate Cristiano Ronaldo has already won the award twice, while Lionel Messi has held it since 2009-2012.

Pope Francis, 78, has been advised by doctors to cut down on pasta intake due to his considerable weight gain since taking office two years ago. The Vatican has also warned him to take a daily walk, similar to his predecessor Pope Benedict XVI. Doctors say the Pope's sedentary lifestyle is exacerbating his sciatica, a nerve condition causing back pain. Despite this, Pope Francis has refused to change his eating habits, jokingly referring to himself as "the undisciplined one".

Google has released an update to its Android software allowing owners to unlock their phone with their voice, known as "trusted voice" or "voice unlock". This feature allows users to simply hear their owner say "OK, Google" to unlock their phone. The feature uses a liveness check to verify the user's identity before granting access. An alternative method to unlock an Android phone is available, which uses facial recognition technology. The feature was first introduced in 2011 as part of Android 4.0, but has been criticized for its potential security risks due to the possibility of static images being used to bypass the system.

Robert Bates, an Oklahoma reserve deputy, has released documents that verify some of his training as a law enforcement officer. The documents show he attended one Taser training class, took three firearms training classes, and qualified 10 times to use a handgun between 2009 and 2014. These training records contradict previous reports that questioned Bates' qualifications due to his lack of firearm proficiency. The documents also reveal that Bates had taken additional training beyond the standard requirements, including 14 classes worth 40 credit hours.

A leading headteacher at Sherborne Preparatory School in Dorset claims that parents have become "dervishes" about their children's education, interfering too much and hindering their natural development. This trend stems from parents being bombarded with information on how to raise children, according to Peter Tait, who warns that parents should trust schools and teachers rather than trying to control every aspect of their child's life. The situation has led to increased reports of parents using social media to intimidate staff, with a survey showing that nearly half of teachers suffer abuse from both parents and pupils.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu criticized the Iran nuclear deal, calling it a "bad deal" and saying it gives Iran too much flexibility. He argued that the deal would allow Iran to maintain its nuclear infrastructure without destroying any centrifuges. Netanyahu's stance is similar to his previous criticism of the deal, which he made during a March speech to Congress. Energy Secretary Ernest Moniz defended the deal, stating it would extend the breakout time period for Iran to build a nuclear bomb. Netanyahu's opposition to the deal is seen as a challenge to President Barack Obama's endorsement, while other lawmakers, such as Senator Lindsey Graham, suggest keeping current sanctions in place for two more years.

Catalans Dragons winger Vincent Duport has been ruled out for the rest of the season due to a shoulder injury sustained in their 33-22 loss to Hull FC. He suffered a ruptured tendon in the match on March 20. This is a significant blow to the team, as Duport had previously overcome previous injuries to return to form. Head coach Laurent Frayssinous expressed disappointment but confidence in his ability to recover. The team's next game is against Wigan on Sunday.

A 36-year-old woman, Samantha Fleming, was reported missing along with her newborn daughter Serenity in Indiana, 180 miles away from their home. She was last seen leaving the home with a woman claiming to be from the Indiana Department of Child Services, but it was later revealed that the woman was actually the alleged kidnapper. Police discovered a body in the same home, wrapped in plastic and buried under a nursery, and found a woman matching the description of the alleged kidnapper at the scene. The body was identified as Fleming's, and the infant was found unharmed at a nearby home.

A 20,000-year-old pyramid is believed to be hidden beneath rubble in West Java, potentially rewriting prehistory in the region and shedding light on a powerful and advanced ancient civilization. This discovery could challenge Egypt's status as the world's oldest pyramid, which dates back to around 2,700 BC. Geologist Dr Danny Hilman believes the site is culturally significant due to its ancient pyramid, built between 9,000 and 20,000 years ago.

A 29-year-old man was stabbed by a 27-year-old man outside a Melbourne nightclub just before the Easter long weekend. The incident occurred when the 27-year-old man returned to the club after being ejected and attacked the 29-year-old security guard from behind. A shocking CCTV recording shows the attack, which resulted in both men sustaining minor facial injuries. The incident happened around 10.13pm on Thursday night, and police were called to the scene shortly afterwards.

Carlisle United manager Keith Curle launched a scathing attack on his team following their 3-1 defeat at Accrington Stanley, criticizing some players for not putting in enough effort. The Cumbrians are struggling in League Two, having lost five games in their last five matches and currently sit two places below the relegation zone. Curle accused some players of lacking character and pride, saying "they're players who don't deserve to be professionals". With only five games remaining until the end of the season, Curle expressed concern about the team's chances of avoiding relegation. A potential open forum for fans may be planned by the club's chairman, Andrew Jenkins.

Victoria's Secret's new campaign features Candice Swanepoel, Elsa Hosk, and Jasmine Tookes showcasing their Dream Angels range of underwear. The campaign promotes the brand's new lingerie line, featuring see-through macs, glossy blow-dries, and push-up bras. Candice leads the glamour, guiding fellow models through an energetic routine while wearing the brand's new range. The campaign aims to make the brand's Dream Angels range a must-have item for the upcoming season.

A Ukrainian-born wannabe singer, Kristina Karo, is suing Hollywood actress Mila Kunis for $5,000, claiming that the actress stole her pet chicken, "Doggie", when they were classmates in Ukraine 25 years ago. Karo alleges that the theft traumatized her and led to her seeking therapy. The lawsuit claims that Karo's own experiences with the stolen chicken have prevented her from pursuing her music dreams.

A 35-year-old father from Milton Keynes claims to have developed an allergy to Nigel Farage after watching him on TV, causing him to break out in a sweat and shake whenever he hears his voice. Richard Howarth, a medical recruitment consultant, says he becomes physically ill if he sees Farage due to a phobia, which he believes is caused by the constant exposure to the Ukip leader's words. A phobia expert agrees, stating that having a strong dislike or fear towards someone can trigger physical reactions, even if there is no actual allergy.

Rahul Kumar, 17, a drunken teenager, jumped into a lions' enclosure at a zoo in Ahmedabad, shouting "Today I kill a lion!" while attempting to escape. He was caught by zoo security and rescued after falling into an eighth moat, which allowed guards to apprehend him. Kumar later claimed he was drunk and thought he had a chance of survival, but ultimately admitted to his actions.

The Havasupai tribe, a small Indian nation in Arizona, USA, is home to the village of Supai, which is accessible only by foot or helicopter/mule. With a population of around 600 people, the tribe lives in harmony with nature, relying on tourism for their primary source of income. The village is nestled at the bottom of Havasu Canyon, in the heart of the Havasupai Nation reservation, and offers a glimpse into traditional life, including a cafe, lodge, post office, school, and LDS chapel. The tribe protects their land and way of life, despite facing challenges such as flooding and drought, and is known for its stunning natural beauty, including the famous Havasu Falls.

A new vaccine against malaria, known as RTS,S, has been developed after 30 years of research and has shown promising results in preventing clinical cases of the disease among young children. The vaccine, which has reached the final stages of testing, could prevent millions of cases globally. Researchers say the vaccine has already shown a substantial contribution to controlling the disease, with an average of 1,363 cases prevented per 1,000 children vaccinated. The vaccine is designed to be used in Africa and could be approved by October, making it the first licensed malaria vaccine worldwide.

Chilean pickpockets have become the most effective thieves operating in central London, according to undercover police teams. Gangs of up to six follow wealthy shoppers in the West End, targeting rich Arab tourists in areas such as Park Lane and Mayfair. The police have identified Chilean pickpockets as the most common type of thief in the area, with many arriving on a six-month visa and working together in teams of three to six members. The police are trying to reduce pickpocket crimes by monitoring CCTV footage and tracking the movements of these gangs.

National Grid has revealed the UK's first new pylon for nearly 90 years, marking a significant milestone in the country's efforts to reduce its reliance on traditional electricity generation methods. This new design, called the T-pylon, features a simpler structure made of eight components and is intended to provide a cleaner and more efficient alternative to traditional lattice pylons. The T-pylon is part of a larger effort to upgrade the UK's transmission infrastructure, with plans to install over 88,000 new pylons across the country. The new pylons will be used to support renewable energy sources like wind and solar power, and will feature a lower profile and reduced maintenance requirements compared to traditional lattice pylons.

A 31-year-old Arizona woman, Holly Nicole Solomon, pleaded guilty to aggravated assault after hitting her husband with their SUV in a Mesa parking lot due to an argument about his decision not to vote in the 2012 presidential election. Solomon, who was six months pregnant, claimed that her family would face hardship if Obama were re-elected. She was charged with aggravated assault and disorderly conduct, but pleaded guilty to the lesser charge after a plea deal. Solomon will serve three and a half years in prison.

Student Drew Hollinshead, 21, stopped in a disabled parking bay while driving in Bournemouth, UK, to help an elderly woman who collapsed on the pavement. A traffic warden issued him a £70 parking ticket despite seeing him assist the woman for just 30 seconds. Hollinshead initially tore up the ticket and threw it away, but later retrieved it and appealed against the fine. His actions were described as "ridiculous" by the warden, who claimed he didn't see anyone else using the space. Hollinshead has since taken to social media to express his frustration and support for others who may be facing similar treatment.

In Pingjiang County, Hunan province, China, workers are constructing a rickety wooden walkway thousands of feet above the ground, without ropes or safety harnesses, to extend a mountain road. The men, who are tasked with assembling scaffolding along the cliff, face nerve-wracking conditions, including heavy loads and little safety equipment. Despite the risks, they continue to work tirelessly to complete the project, which is part of an effort to attract tourists to the area. The walkway is being built for tourists to enjoy, but officials hope it will also draw even more visitors to the region.

Two NHS hospitals, Pennine Acute Hospitals NHS Trust and Royal Oldham, have faced criticism for their handling of maternity care after a series of high-profile deaths involving babies and mothers. An independent investigation found significant failings in risk management, inadequate planning, and poor communication, leading to the deaths of ten babies and three mothers between December 2013 and July 2019. The investigation revealed that national guidelines for treating obese mothers were not followed, and that the root cause of many deaths was not always identified. The trusts have apologized for the harm caused and are taking steps to address the issues, including strengthening clinical leadership and improving risk management.

Australian cricketer Aaron Finch has undergone surgery on his left hamstring and will face up to three months without playing due to a high-grade injury sustained during the Indian Premier League. He underwent scans confirming the injury and was initially expected to miss several months before undergoing surgery. Finch, captain of Australia's World Cup-winning team, will now begin his rehabilitation process and is expected to return within 12 weeks. Finch previously played Test cricket but was excluded from the Australia squad for their upcoming series against West Indies and Ashes tour.

Gordon Elliott trains Irishman AP McCoy's mount, Cause of Causes, which won the Melling Chase at Aintree despite being considered as an alternative to Shutthefrontdoor. McCoy rode the gelding to victory, leading a strong field with Don Cossack, who took part in the Melling Chase. Elliott prefers to focus on Cause of Causes' win rather than arranging jockey Paul Carberry for the upcoming Grand National.

Vince Cable, the former Labour politician, prides himself on being the Tories' bogeyman in the Coalition Cabinet. He wants a substantial role in government and envisions working with the Conservatives again, despite being described as a closet Labour politician by others. Cable has previously expressed admiration for the Tories, but now seems to be positioning himself as a potential candidate to replace George Osborne as Chancellor. His warm words for the Tories are notable given the efforts to "decapitate" him, suggesting he may still have a place in the Conservative Party.

A survey of 2000 British workers found that the average worker sits through 6,239 meetings in their career, with 60% finding most meetings "pretty pointless". Many workers also admit to catching 40 winks during meetings, with 70% constantly zoning out while in meetings. A significant proportion of workers believe their team members sneakily arrange offsite meetings to avoid spending time away from the office, and 45% feel that their company wastes money on travel costs. Despite this, many workers still prioritize meetings, with 70% saying they constantly zone out while in meetings, and 45% feeling that conferences calls are often just as efficient as face-to-face meetings.

A math problem was created for 14-year-olds called "The Birthday Problem" where Cheryl gave Albert and Bernard a list of 10 possible birthdays in different months. They tried to figure out Cheryl's birthday based on the clues provided by each other. 

Cheryl initially told Albert the month and day of her birthday, while she kept the day secret. She then told Bernard the same information, allowing him to deduce that his own birthday couldn't be in May or June due to unique dates. With this new information, Bernard narrowed down the options to three possibilities: July 16, August 15, and August 17. After Albert confirmed that he didn't know the birthday, Bernard realized that if Cheryl's birthday was in July, it would mean that Albert knew it wasn't in May or June, leaving July as the correct answer.

Army Major John Jackson and his wife Carolyn engaged in "a regimen of abuse and neglect" with their three young foster children over several years, leaving them with physical injuries and health problems. The couple was charged with abusing their foster children after a federal prosecutor revealed that one of their biological children had died due to the abuse. The Jacksons' first child abuse trial resulted in a mistrial due to a procedural error, but the current trial marks the second time they face charges related to their foster children. The couple has three biological children and three adopted children, and the abuse allegedly took place at their home in Mount Holly, New Jersey.

Real Madrid are set to be without Karim Benzema for their Champions League quarter-final second leg clash against Atletico Madrid due to a knee injury sustained during a 3-1 loss to Malaga. The French striker will miss Wednesday's match despite Madrid boss Carlo Ancelotti saying he will return for the next game. Madrid's Gareth Bale and Luka Modric are also likely to miss the clash. Meanwhile, Barcelona coach Luis Enrique is hailed as the best coach in his first 50 games by Mundo Deportivo, while Juventus are looking to secure their Serie A title with a win over Torino in their upcoming match.

Thieves targeting 294 security vaults in Berlin and London, including a £60m heist in London, bear strikingly similar traits. The Hatton Garden raid may have been carried out by the same group, possibly in Berlin two years earlier. Both heists involved tunnelling and drilling to gain access to valuable items, such as diamonds, gold, and silver. The thieves used disguises, including dressing as construction workers, to blend in with the surroundings.

A young girl's heart-wrenching reaction to witnessing the tragic death of her father, Simba's lion father Mufasa, in Disney's "The Lion King" has been captured on camera by her father, Barles Charkley. The video shows the child, only 18 months old, reacting to the scene with a crestfallen expression, as the soundtrack plays a mournful score by composer Hans Zimmer. The clip has gone viral, garnering over 4 million views, and has left many people feeling emotionally moved. The scene is widely regarded as one of Disney's most tear-jerking moments, and its impact is evident in the child's reaction, which includes brushing away tears and gathering her blanket in despair.

A couple in their 40s became victims of age discrimination after their bank, HSBC, rejected a £250,000 mortgage application due to the husband's age, which was deemed too high. The bank initially offered the couple a decision-in-principle, but later refused to proceed due to the husband's age, citing age restrictions for interest-only loans. The couple complained and were ultimately ordered to pay £500 for distress and inconvenience, as well as to reconsider their loan application. This marks the first time an age-based decision has been ruled unfair by the Financial Ombudsman Service.

A Texas veterinarian, Dr. Kristen Lindsey, was fired from her job after posting a photo of herself holding a dead cat on Facebook, claiming it was a "good feral tomcat" with an arrow through its head. The incident sparked widespread outrage, with many calling for charges against her due to concerns about animal welfare. Lindsey's actions have led to a public backlash, with some calling for her to be held accountable for her actions. An investigation is underway, and Lindsey could potentially face charges related to animal cruelty.

A pioneering facial surgeon, Professor Ninian Peckitt, is accused of repeatedly punching a patient in the face to correct a fracture caused by an industrial accident. The alleged incident occurred in February 2012 when Peckitt worked as an honorary locum consultant in oral and maxillo-facial surgery at Ipswich Hospital. A Medical Practitioners Tribunal Service hearing was held in Manchester, where Peckitt denied the allegations, claiming he digitally manipulated the patient's face during a closed reduction procedure. However, witnesses testified that Peckitt hit the patient, and the tribunal ultimately decided that he should be struck off the medical register due to his actions.

Actor Ben Powers, best known for his role as Thelma's husband Keith on the CBS sitcom "Good Times", has died at the age of 64 after passing away at his New Bedford, Massachusetts home on April 6. His family has not disclosed the cause of his death. Powers played the character of Keith in the show's sixth and final season between 1978-1979. A tribute from his on-screen wife Bern Nadette Stanis followed, expressing her condolences to the family.

Derby went into the game needing to win to keep their slim hopes of automatic promotion alive, but managed to hold on for a 1-1 draw against Brentford at the iPro Stadium. Alex Pritchard scored a stunning strike in stoppage time to put his side ahead, only for Darren Bent to equalize in the final seconds. The Bees dominated the game for much of the match, but missed several chances to take the lead, while Derby also had opportunities to score. Despite being down 1-0 at halftime, the Rams fought back to grab a point in stoppage time, thanks to Bent's 10th goal of the season.

A gang of armed robbers used pink umbrellas to hide themselves as they stole £145,000 from 13 shops in a two-month crime spree in the West Midlands. The gang targeted supermarkets, convenience stores, and electrical shops, stealing cash and valuable items such as cars and cars' parts. CCTV footage showed the gang using umbrellas to conceal their entrance during raids, and they also threatened shop workers with hammers, knives, and screwdrivers. Four members of the gang - Ashleigh Evans, Marcus Morgan, Liam Bell, and Trea Richardson - were jailed for their roles in the 13 robberies, with some receiving lengthy prison sentences.

Italian Alex Bellini, an explorer, plans to spend a year living inside a ball-shaped capsule on top of an iceberg in Greenland, seeking funding for his project "Adrift". The capsule, designed to withstand extreme temperatures and potential iceberg flips, will allow him to observe the melting process and raise awareness about global warming and climate change. Bellini aims to document the changes in the iceberg's center of mass and potentially discover whether it will flip before being thrown into the air. With a focus on education and sustainability, Bellini hopes to inspire others to take action against climate change through his project.

A photograph circulated on social media site SnapChat appears to show Geelong College principal Andrew Barr watching pornography in his office while on-duty. The photo, taken by a student, shows Barr surfing for explicit content through a computer screen. An investigation revealed that the photograph was taken during a search of Barr's computer, leading to his resignation from the role. The incident sparked a serious breach of the school's standards, despite an investigation finding no evidence of wrongdoing.

A 30-year-old man, Francis Pusok, was beaten by police on horseback after fleeing his home in Southern California on Thursday, resulting in over 80 swipes from helicopters capturing the brutal attack. Pusok, who had been arrested for identity theft charges, was subjected to a prolonged and intense beating by multiple deputies, including a sergeant and detective, who claimed his taser was ineffective due to his loose clothing. The incident has raised concerns about police brutality and excessive force, particularly given Pusok's previous run-ins with law enforcement, including threatening to kill a deputy and shooting a puppy. Ten officers involved in the incident have been placed on paid administrative leave, and an investigation is ongoing.

Mohammed "Jihadi John" Emwazi, a former British citizen, came into contact with Hizb ut-Tahrir while studying at Westminster University. The extremist Islamist group has been linked to attacks in Syria, including those carried out by ISIS. Members of Hizb ut-Tahrir, including Mohammed "Jihadi John", have been known to recruit individuals through universities, including those in the UK. A would-be MP, Maajid Nawaz, was found to have been in contact with the group while studying at Manchester University, and was later convicted of promoting extremism.

A tropical fruit called the "Bouea macrophylla" or "mango plum" is being stocked by Marks & Spencer in the UK, after years of working with Thai growers. This fruit has a bright orange edible skin, firmer than a plum, and a sweet taste similar to an Alphonso mango but with a softer texture. It is expected to be a big hit among customers, who appreciate trying new and interesting fruit. The fruit is smaller than a mango and will be available for purchase this weekend.

In South Africa, white solidarity groups are protesting the removal of a statue of British colonialist Cecil Rhodes from the University of Cape Town. The statue, which depicts Rhodes as a symbol of imperialism, was removed after months of protests by black students and staff. The decision to remove the statue has sparked further protests, with some calling for its preservation and others demanding its removal due to its association with racist ideologies. The controversy surrounding the statue has led to clashes between protesters and counter-protesters, with some groups accusing politicians and businessmen associated with the statue of racism.

A 18-year-old Welsh footballer, Hannah Bluck, from Porthcawl, South Wales, has had her promising career halted due to a rare condition called avascular necrosis, which causes bone death due to poor blood supply. The condition led to her leg bone collapsing into her ankle, ruling her out of the game for two years. Bluck, a teenage international footballer, had previously played for Wales youth national teams at various levels, including U19, U17, and U16. Her condition has left her unable to kick a ball since, and she is currently undergoing treatment to save her remaining bone.

Edinson Cavani has denied rumors of a rift between him and teammate Zlatan Ibrahimovic, insisting that the only issue is being played out of position. Cavani has expressed frustration at being shoehorned into a front three and not playing in his favored striker role. Despite this, Cavani maintains a respectful relationship with Ibrahimovic, who celebrated PSG's 3-2 win over Marseille. The Swedish forward has also challenged Marseilles midfielder Mario Lemina after a disagreement with the referee during the match.

The England U-17 team for the upcoming UEFA European Under-17 Championship has been announced by coach John Peacock. The team includes several talented young players from Premier League clubs such as Jay Dasilva of Chelsea and Ike Ugbo of Chelsea, as well as Arsenal duo Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi. The squad also features defenders like Paul Woolston and Will Huffer, midfielders like Trent Arnold and Herbie Kane, and forwards like Layton Ndukwu and Stephy Mavididi. The team will face off against Italy, Holland, and Ireland in Group D, starting with a match against Italy on May 7.

Fireball Cinnamon Whisky, a popular party shot, has experienced rapid growth since its introduction in 2007, becoming the fastest-growing big brand in America. Despite being sold in bars and online, Fireball has surpassed Jagermeister as America's top party shot of choice, with sales increasing from under $2 million in 2011 to over $130 million in 2019. The brand gained traction through social media and events, particularly among young drinkers and women, who appreciate its sweet and spicy flavor profile. However, some critics have raised concerns about the ingredient propylene glycol found in the liquor, leading to a recall in several European countries.

Researchers at the University of Montana conducted a study involving 11 male athletes who were asked to eat either fast food or a high-protein supplement after a 90-minute endurance workout. The study found that eating fast food resulted in similar performance and glycogen levels compared to consuming a high-protein supplement. During recovery periods, the glycogen levels in both groups remained stable, suggesting that short bursts of intense exercise can be just as effective as longer periods of rest. The findings suggest that eating fast food may be a viable option for those looking to improve their athletic performance.

Gael Monfils defeated Roger Federer 6-4, 7-6 in a thrilling last-16 encounter at the Monte Carlo Masters. Monfils' athleticism and shotmaking impressed, bringing all the good parts of his game to bear against the 33-year-old former world No 1. Monfils celebrated his victory with a beaming grin, while Federer shook hands with him at the end of the match. Monfils' impressive display earned him a spot in the quarter-finals, where he faces Grigor Dimitrov. Monfils' 22 winners helped him secure the win, making it a memorable night for the Frenchman.

Revered Al Sharpton appeared in North Charleston to deliver a sermon on the Walter Scott case, addressing the need for reform around national policing legislation. He preached at Charity Missionary Baptist Church and criticized the police department for their handling of the incident, which resulted in Scott's fatal shooting. Sharpton also met with local officials, including North Charleston Mayor Keith Summey and Police Chief Eddie Driggers, to discuss the case. Sharpton denied allegations that Scott's family did not want to attend his funeral due to media attention.

Earth's diversity of life is increasing despite dire warnings about mass extinctions, according to Stewart Brand, president of the Long Now Foundation. Brand claims that focusing solely on extinction threats can be counterproductive, instead suggesting that conservation efforts should prioritize recovery and reintroduction of extinct species. The five major mass extinctions in Earth's history - Ordovician-Silurian, Late Devonian, Permian, Triassic-Jurassic, and Cretaceous-Tertiary - have resulted in the elimination of 70% or more of all species. Brand advocates for biotechnology to improve genetic diversity and notes that many species are already recovering, while conservationists warn that human activities pose a significant threat to species survival.

ISIS controls various aspects of governance, including documents related to vaccination schedules, fishing methods, and rent disputes, with officials enforcing strict Sharia law conditions. The group preserves the prior system, but adapts it to suit its own interpretations of Islamic law. Its Health Department provides medical services, including hospitals for those affected by natural disasters. Daily life in areas under ISIS control is marked by reports of violence and repression, with detainees speaking from Iraqi jails about their experiences. The group's governing principles emphasize the importance of preserving Islamic heritage and enforcing strict punishments for non-compliance.

A triple tragedy unfolded in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, when a 2-year-old child was struck and killed by a van driven by Archie Brown Jr, who then took his own life in revenge. The 15-year-old boy who was riding in the van was also fatally shot. The driver of the van, who remains unidentified, was shot dead at the scene. An investigation is ongoing, and authorities are seeking the perpetrator.

The odds on the new royal baby being a girl have tumbled after a bookmaker revealed that 90% of bets placed on the sex have shifted towards a female child. The betting on the baby's date of birth has also increased, with the 18th, 19th, and 20th April being the most popular choices. The majority of punters believe the Duchess of Cambridge will give birth to a girl, with Ladbrokes spokesman Jessica Bridge commenting that "money talks" and punters are convinced Kate will give birth to a baby girl soon. Preparations have begun at the Lindo Wing, where the Duchess of Cambridge is expecting her third child, while Sweden's Crown Princess Victoria, 37, is preparing to welcome her fifth child, a son.

Holly Willoughby and Davina McCall, two long-time friends and TV personalities, have joined forces in their first campaign together for Garnier Nutrisse, celebrating finding their perfect hair shade. They star in the campaign, showcasing their gorgeous hairstyles in the process. The duo, both 47 and 34 respectively, were spotted cuddling up to each other and larking around with their hair pulled over their mouths to resemble a moustache. The pair have also extended their partnership with This Morning, where they will appear in a new campaign promoting Garnier Nutrisse.

A Brooklyn woman, Ellanora Arthur Baidoo, has asked a New York judge to accept "just got served" as a valid method of serving her husband, Victor Sena Blood-Dzraku, with divorce papers. Baidoo has been trying to divorce him for several years, but was unable to find a way to serve him due to his refusal to provide a fixed address or employment. She used social media platforms such as Facebook to try to deliver the papers, but was unsuccessful. A judge has agreed to allow her to use these platforms as a means of service, citing the advent and ascendency of social media as a new frontier for delivering legal documents.

The Turin Shroud, a piece of linen believed to be the burial cloth of Jesus Christ, went on display to the public for the first time in five years. Over one million people have already booked their spots to see the cloth, which features the image of a man who appears to have been crucified. The shroud is on display until June 24, 2015, and is valued for its symbolic significance as a representation of Christ's suffering. The Catholic Church does not confirm whether the image was created by Jesus himself or if it is a medieval forgery.

A Mayfair mansion that was once the site of a milking parlour has gone on the market for £25million. This newly-built mansion was constructed on the site of a former milking parlour in Mayfair, which dates back to Tudor times and served as a hub of agricultural trade for years. The property features four bedrooms, each with its own en-suite bathroom, and a grand piano in the marbled hall. The house boasts a rooftop garden, steam room, and Jacuzzi bath, making it an impressive addition to the area.

Aidan Turner, the heartthrob star of the BBC period drama Poldark, has been signed up for a second series of the show. The series, which follows Ross Poldark's journey after returning home from the American War of Independence, was a huge success, attracting 8.1 million viewers per episode and helping BBC1 to reach an 'outstanding start' this year. The show, based on Winston Graham's novels, features Aidan Turner reprising his role as the brooding Ross Poldark alongside co-star Eleanor Tomlinson, who plays his love interest and wife Demelza. The second series will cover the next three books in the Poldark saga, including the titles "Jeremy" and "George".

A gastrointestinal illness has affected 100 people on the cruise ship Celebrity Infinity, according to the Centers for Disease Control. The illness has caused 95 passengers to suffer from vomiting, diarrhea, and other symptoms, while five crew members have also fallen ill. The CDC has not determined the cause of the outbreak, but has taken steps to address it, including increasing cleaning and disinfection procedures and testing for the afflicted. This is the third time the Celebrity Infinity has experienced such an outbreak, which occurred in 2006 and 2013.

UltraHaptics is a company developing a technology that creates tactile three-dimensional shapes out of thin air using ultrasound, allowing users to experience virtual objects and environments in a more immersive way. Their system uses sound waves to project sensations onto the environment, creating invisible yet tangible interfaces. This technology has the potential to revolutionize various fields, including electronic devices, virtual reality, and home appliances. By combining UltraHaptics' technology with other emerging technologies like virtual reality, the company aims to change the way people interact with electronic devices and create new forms of entertainment.

Jodie Barden, 28, is a mother to eight-year-old Ella and one-year-old Chloe, both suffering from Cockayne Syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by premature ageing and a small head size. Despite the girls' life expectancy of just 12, Jodie has arranged for their funerals, having already planned for both of them. The couple, along with their husband Luke, 28, have taken steps to ensure their daughters' comfort and happiness until they pass away. Their efforts include raising funds for a Cockayne Syndrome charity and participating in various activities together.

Damon Muller, a 11-year-old boy from Gladstone in central Queensland, has a rare autoimmune disease called Juvenile Dermatomyositis (JDM). Since being diagnosed in November, he has experienced significant symptoms, including almost doubling in size due to swelling and bloating, and developing severe rash on his body. The disease affects the muscles closest to the trunk of his body, causing limited mobility and discomfort. His parents, Nicci Moynahan, describe the experience as "very scary" and note that there is currently limited support available in Australia for the disease.

Chelsy Davy, a Zimbabwean-born British socialite, debuted a grown-up and glamorous style as she stepped out in a sophisticated summer outfit for a London restaurant launch on Tuesday. She paired a white layered chiffon top with navy trousers and tan wedges, and completed the look with a croc-print clutch bag. The 29-year-old was seen laughing and joking with friend Irene Forte at the launch party for The Ivy Chelsea Garden.

A lack of iron, especially in women, can trigger hair loss due to reduced oxygen delivery to the hair follicle. Taking iron supplements may help alleviate symptoms, but their effectiveness varies depending on individual cases. Eating protein-rich foods, such as meat, fish, and eggs, is essential for maintaining healthy hair. Research suggests that certain amino acids like l-lysine may play a role in hair loss prevention. While some supplements claim to promote hair growth, there is limited scientific evidence to support their effectiveness.

Orangutan Suma, aged 36, suffers from arthritis, a painful condition affecting middle-aged animals like herself. To assess its progression, doctors anaesthetised Suma and took X-rays to examine her hips and ankles. The examination revealed significant changes, prompting a steroid injection to reduce pain for months or potentially years. A full check-up included checking her ears, teeth, and eyes, as well as taking urine and blood samples.
party: Louis returned to his hotel in London's Soho on Thursday, apparently after the pictures of him with the roll up were taken - he is wearing the very same Brooklyn sweater as in the images.

Beijing's historic landmarks, such as the Temple of Heaven, Summer Palace, and Western Qing Tombs, are showcased in a series of 100-year-old photos taken between 1900 and 1911 during the Qing dynasty. These photographs offer a glimpse into China's last imperial era, which ended in 1911, and provide a stark contrast to modern-day Beijing, which is one of the most populous cities in the world and visited by millions. The quiet scenes depict landmarks with few visitors, showcasing the city's transformation over time. Many of the photos feature iconic structures like the Forbidden City, Yuquan Mountain, and the Temple of Heaven, which have been designated UNESCO World Heritage Sites.

Australian capital cities can expect record-breaking profits on their properties at auctions this weekend due to a surge in home resales recording a gross loss at an all-time low rate. Home resales showing a profit were at an all-time high, with 8.6% of homes recording a loss and 32.3% selling for more than double their original price. The highest-profile sale is a property at 14 Ridge Street in South Perth, where the owners are expected to make a profit of over $3 million when it goes under the hammer. Meanwhile, Melbourne properties have seen extremely low resale losses, with 5.6% of homes selling for more than double their original price.

Tony Pulis led West Bromwich Albion to a 2-0 victory over his former club Crystal Palace, wearing his signature gritty and resilient playing style, which includes a distinctive touchline attire consisting of a cap, track suit, and shiny white trainers. The 57-year-old manager insisted on wearing this uniform despite having to wear it indoors due to league rules. His team dominated the remainder of the game, scoring two goals through James Morrison's headed strike and Craig Gardner's 30-yard strike. Despite being met by Palace's stubborn defense, West Brom held on to secure a crucial point.

Crystal Palace co-chairman Steve Parish described a "great moment" as he celebrated the club's 2-1 win over Manchester City. He posed for a picture with Palace manager Alan Pardew, England boss Roy Hodgson, and Bill Wyman, one of the original members of The Rolling Stones and avid Palace fan. Parish shared a photo on Instagram, captioning it "Great moment for me".

The Solar Impulse 2, an experimental plane attempting to fly around the world without fuel, has been grounded due to bad weather in China. The plane, piloted by Bertrand Piccard and Andre Borschberg, has been stuck in Chongqing for nearly two and a half weeks, with a planned overnight stop in Nanjing cancelled. Despite technical issues, the team is working to fix the plane and resume flights, but the delay is expected to push them past the halfway point of their journey. The Solar Impulse 2 is designed to store energy during the day to power its motors at night, and it has already completed flights in Oman, India, and Myanmar.

Jordan Spieth made a triumphant return to the Masters after breaking multiple records, including setting a new Augusta record with a 4-stroke victory. Visiting the Empire State Building, Spieth became the second-youngest champion in tournament history, just 23 years old. He was presented with the green jacket by Bubba Watson and celebrated with a selfie. Spieth's impressive performance earned praise from Justin Rose, who called him "one of the best" and noted that golf is craving a rivalry, particularly between Spieth and Rory McIlroy. With a strong finish, Spieth rose to No 2 in the world rankings, solidifying his position as a rising star in the golf world.

David Cameron's home, particularly his kitchen, has sparked debate about its level of refinement due to its association with the "toff" class. His belongings, such as a cafetière and cookery book shelf, seem to align with the expected standards of upper-class households. However, critics argue that his lack of clutter-free appliances and unconventional decor, like a reed diffuser, detract from the image. Despite this, experts praise his collection of books, including Mary Berry's cookbooks, which demonstrate a commitment to quality and tradition.
Sears had originally planned to marry at a chapel within the grounds of Cromlix House, which Murray purchased two years ago, but later opted for the 300-seat cathedral.

Alastair Cook has been working on a new, more open stance with former England batting coach Graham Gooch over the past few months, but in the first Test against the West Indies, he appeared to have overdone it. A comparison of pictures shows that his front foot is now slightly open but far past the line of leg stump, indicating a long way to go to adjust to the delivery and set himself. This is particularly concerning given Cook's history of struggling with his front foot movement, and he may need to work on his technique further before returning to full form.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. He has enjoyed seven successful years at the Catalan club, winning four Spanish titles and the Champions League twice. Alves's agent, Dinorah Santana, confirmed that he had rejected a three-year contract extension, which would have required him to take part in 60% of matches for the club. This decision comes after Alves kept a close eye on Almeria midfielder Edgar Mendez during a recent match.

Robin Ellis, now 73, was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes by chance in 1999, aged 58, after a friend was diagnosed with prostate cancer. Despite being slim all his life, he retains the physique that made him famous as Ross Poldark. His mother had type 1 diabetes, which is an entirely different type, and he suspects it was just a coincidence. With the help of new research, Robin has learned to manage his condition through lifestyle changes, including eliminating sugar and refined carbs, and writing cookbooks for others with diabetes.

Aaron Hernandez, a former New England Patriots tight end, has been moved to a new prison after being convicted of first-degree murder and sentenced to life behind bars. He was transferred to the maximum-security Souza-Baranowski Correctional Center in Shirley, Massachusetts, where he will serve his sentence. Hernandez was convicted of killing 27-year-old Odin Lloyd in 2013, who was dating the sister of Hernandez's fiancée. Hernandez spent his first week in prison before being relocated due to concerns over his safety.

A 35-year-old man named Jamie Robbins handed himself into police a year after stealing £1,600 from a convenience store in Birmingham with an accomplice due to preferring life in jail. The pair robbed the Select 'n' Save shop on January 13, 2014, and were caught when one of the accomplices failed to wait in the getaway car. Robbins pleaded guilty to robbery and possession of a bladed article and was sentenced to four-and-a-half years in prison. He later confessed to the crime and revealed that he had previously considered going back to jail, but changed his mind after discovering his girlfriend was pregnant.

A newborn camel named Injaz, who was cloned from the ovarian cells of a slaughtered camel in 2009, is pregnant and expected to give birth to a calf later this year. The birth of Injaz, whose name means "achievement" in Arabic, marks the world's first successful cloning of a camel. Scientists claim that Injaz is genetically identical to the original camel, confirming its fertility and ability to reproduce like a naturally born animal. The discovery is seen as a breakthrough in preserving the genetics of the camel population, which is valued for its unique characteristics and uses in agriculture and conservation.

Sir Alex Ferguson, the former Manchester United manager, revealed why he rates Cristiano Ronaldo above Lionel Messi during an interview with John Parrott over a frame of snooker. Ferguson cited Ronaldo's versatility, athleticism, and ability to perform under pressure as reasons for his choice. He also praised Ronaldo's ability to adapt to different teams and situations, which he felt made him more valuable to any team. Ferguson's comments were met with agreement from Parrott, who noted that Ronaldo's skills on the pitch translate well to other sports like snooker.

A Fenerbahce team bus carrying players and coaching staff was shot at while returning from an away game in Trabzon, Turkey. The driver appeared to have been hit by a bullet, but none of the players or staff were seriously injured. The bus driver suffered a head injury and was taken to hospital. A suspect has been identified as having used a shotgun to attack the bus.

Nicola Sturgeon, the newly elected First Minister of Scotland, made a strong impression on the national stage, delivering a confident and charismatic address that earned her the nickname "GSM Sturgeon". With her poise and self-assurance, she took center stage alongside Judy Murray, who described her as "GSM Sturgeon" in a tweet. This marked a significant shift in tone, as Sturgeon's previous persona was often associated with controversy and division. Now, she appears to be a more conciliatory and less divisive figure, with polls suggesting she could wield significant influence over future government formation in Westminster.

Declan Fitzpatrick, a 31-year-old prop for Ulster Rugby, has announced his retirement from professional rugby due to multiple concussions. The Irish prop experienced "numbered" concussive episodes in recent seasons, prompting a referral to a neurologist who advised stopping play. Fitzpatrick played 98 times for Ulster and earned seven caps for Ireland, winning the last one against New Zealand in 2013. Despite struggling with symptoms, Fitzpatrick expressed gratitude to Ulster Rugby and the IRFU for their support throughout his career.

Oregon-based defense contractor FLIR Systems Inc. has agreed to pay $9.5 million to settle bribery charges filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). The SEC alleged that the company paid expensive trips and gifts to Middle Eastern government officials, including luxury watches and vacations, in exchange for sales of thermal imaging equipment. Two employees, Stephen Timms and Yasser Ramahi, have agreed to settle SEC charges and pay financial penalties. The SEC said the company's deficient financial controls allowed employees to circumvent laws prohibiting gifts and travel expenses related to official business.

Floyd Mayweather Jr is preparing for his highly anticipated $300 million mega fight against Manny Pacquiao, which will take place on May 2 at the MGM Grand in Las Vegas. A short promotional video released by Showtime shows a glimpse into Mayweather's intense training camp, where he is focusing on perfecting his skills and pushing himself to the limit. Mayweather weighs in close to the 147-pound welterweight limit, having recently dropped below it. The two fighters have been documenting their training camps on social media, building anticipation for what promises to be one of the most epic battles in boxing history.

A 58-year-old woman, Diwalinen Vankar, bravely fought off a 13ft-long crocodile with a wooden washing paddle after her 19-year-old daughter Kanta was grabbed by one while trying to wash their clothes in the Vishwamitri River in west India. The incident occurred when a mugger crocodile attacked Kanta's right leg, dragging her into the river. Diwalinen Vankar used her washing paddle to hit the crocodile's head, freeing her daughter after a 10-minute battle. The mother's quick thinking and bravery saved her daughter's life, and she suffered a leg injury.

The article highlights the 20 greatest shots ever seen at Augusta National Golf Club, counting down from 20 to 1. These iconic moments showcase incredible skill and clutch performances in the Masters Tournament. Among them are notable victories by Mark O'Meara, who shot two birdies in three holes from the 15th on Sunday, and Charl Schwartzel, who won his first major in 2011 with a memorable eagle on the 11th hole. Other notable mentions include Billy Joe Patton's hole-in-one, Seve Ballesteros's dramatic victory, Byron Nelson's comeback, Vijay Singh's impressive ace, Nick Faldo's nerveless approach, and Louis Oosthuizen's record-breaking long iron shot.

Jaclyn Methuen, a 30-year-old woman who nearly left her husband Ryan Ranellone at the altar due to his perceived lack of attractiveness, continues to keep him in the "friend zone" during their romantic getaway to Puerto Rico. She admits to wanting to be a "runaway bride" in a recent confession. Meanwhile, Ryan DeNiro struggles with marital problems with his new wife Jessica Castro, who accuses him of calling her "trashy" after seeing a photo of her with a different man. Additionally, Davina Kullar, a 34-year-old woman, and her husband Sean Varricchio face marital issues during their honeymoon in Colorado, with Davina expressing frustration with their lack of communication.

Mullah Mohammed Omar, still considered the leader of the Taliban's self-declared Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan, has been the subject of a new biography released by the Taliban's Cultural Commission. The 11-page document commemorates the 19th anniversary of an April 4, 1996, meeting where Afghans swore allegiance to Omar. The biography aims to dispel rumors of his demise, despite speculation suggesting he may have died. Born in 1960 in a village called Chah-i-Himmat in Afghanistan's Kandahar province, Omar studied at a religious school and rose through the ranks of the armed Afghan opposition known as the mujahedeen.

The NFL investigation into the New England Patriots' alleged use of deflated footballs in the AFC Championship game has been ongoing since January, with the league hiring attorney Ted Wells to investigate. The investigation, led by NFL Executive Vice President Jeff Pash, aims to determine if the Patriots intentionally deflated the footballs to gain an unfair advantage. The investigation has already lasted over three months, with the Patriots ultimately beating the Indianapolis Colts 45-7 in the championship game. Quarterback Tom Brady called the accusation "ridiculous", while Patriots owner Robert Kraft expressed hopes that the league would apologize if the investigation finds no wrongdoing.

Bianca Gascoigne, the daughter of football legend Paul Gascoigne, was mugged by a gang of eight on bikes in central London while walking with her phone, which reportedly contained private texts from her father. The thieves grabbed her phone and attempted to steal her bag before running away when she fought back. Bianca Gascoigne took to social media to express her anger towards the attackers, calling them "lowlifes" and stating that they could access her private texts. The incident occurred on Tuesday afternoon, leaving her visibly shaken.

Aberdeen striker Adam Rooney wants to prevent a disappointing conclusion to the season for his team, who are currently trailing Celtic by 8 points. Despite having a strong record against the other top-flight teams, Rooney believes they need to focus on preventing a "green-and-white party" from taking place at Pittodrie on May 11 if they hope to win the league. Rooney has been instrumental in Aberdeen's success this season, netting 27 goals and leading the team to several victories. With Celtic currently sitting 8 points clear of second-placed Aberdeen, Rooney expects the Dons to be highly motivated to secure a title win. Rooney himself has already won the Scotland Player of the Year award and scored the winning goal in Aberdeen's 4-0 victory over Dundee United last weekend.

Marion "Suge" Knight, a former rap mogul, was ordered to stand trial for murder and other charges related to a deadly hit-and-run confrontation on the set of the biopic "Straight Outta Compton". The incident occurred on the movie set of the film, where Knight was driving and allegedly ran over two men, killing one, Terry Carter, 55. Knight faces up to life in prison if convicted. His defense team argued that Knight was the victim, while prosecutors claimed he was the aggressor. Knight's attorney, Matthew Fletcher, defended his client, stating that Knight stood his ground in a mutual combat situation.

Hillary Clinton's astroturf candidacy is in full swing in Iowa, where she met with a group of young Iowans at a coffee shop in LeClaire, Iowa, where campaign staffer Troy Price asked them to meet her at a private event. The meeting was arranged through a third-party organization, and the attendees were later revealed to be part of Clinton's nascent campaign. The event was seen as a strategic move to counter her image as a cold, calculating politician. The incident has raised questions about the authenticity of Clinton's campaign, which has been criticized for staging meetings with ordinary citizens to promote its message.

A new HIV self-testing kit has been launched in the UK, enabling people to test their HIV status at home using a small amount of blood from a finger-prick sample. This 99.7% accurate test allows individuals to determine if they have HIV antibodies without the need for a doctor's visit or appointment. Estimated 26,000 people in the UK are unaware of having HIV, and those who do not know may be unknowingly spreading the virus. The test provides a quick result in just 15 minutes, making it accessible to anyone who wants to know their HIV status.

In California's prisons, many inmates are held in Level IV maximum-security facilities, where about 97% are gang affiliated. To address this issue, the California Department of Corrections has established Sensitive Needs Housing Units, providing a safer environment for former gang members who want to leave their violent lives behind. These exclusive units offer a chance at a new life, free from gang activity, and help facilitate the transition out of gang membership. However, even within these units, gang affiliation and violence persist, with some inmates continuing to engage in violent behavior despite being housed separately.

A personal injury claims company, Direct Assist, has collapsed after being fined £80,000 by the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) for plaguing households with nuisance calls. The company told one complainant that they would be called for three years until they made a claim despite repeated requests to remove their details from the Telephone Preference Service (TPS). The ICO found that Direct Assist instructed staff to use TPS-listed numbers, despite warnings from the TPS, leading to 525 complaints. The company's CEO, Richard Lloyd, defended his actions, saying he drove "a coach and horses" through cold calling rules, but acknowledged that the ICO had taken decisive action against him.

Jose Mourinho's defensive prowess has been instrumental in securing Premier League titles for both Chelsea and Manchester City, with a third victory likely at the end of the current season. The Portuguese manager boasts an impressive clean sheets record, having shut out opponents in 53.4% of his 189 Premier League matches. This achievement surpasses Rafa Benitez's record, who managed to keep clean sheets in 44.9% of his games. Mourinho's defensive stalwartness has earned him the title of best clean sheets percentage record holder in Premier League history.

A 15-year-old girl from Cape Town, South Africa was detained by authorities at Cape Town International Airport after they received information that she was planning to leave the country to join the terrorist group ISIS. The girl had been using social media platforms to interact with strangers and read materials suggesting she wanted to join the group. She was arrested and later released back to her family's care after officials conducted an investigation. The incident highlights concerns about the recruitment of young people to extremist groups like ISIS.

Ben Powers, who played Thelma's husband Keith Anderson on the final season of the classic CBS sitcom "Good Times", has passed away. He was 64 years old and died on April 6 in New Bedford, Massachusetts. Powers joined the show in 1978 and played Keith, a professional football player, and later had a recurring role as "Moochie" on the CBS detective drama show "Mike Hammer".

A 39-year-old man from Melbourne's southwest was shot numerous times while sitting in his mother's Altona Meadows driveway at 2am on Sunday. He was identified as Karl Kay, a father of six, and died shortly after paramedics arrived at the scene. Neighbors reported hearing screeching tires and saw him being shot before dying. The motive behind the shooting remains unknown, and no witnesses came forward to report it.

A photographer visited the luxurious Ulusaba Game Reserve in South Africa's Sabi Sands, where he crawled under an open-sided Land Rover to get close to a 4,500lb horned rhino. He met three more rhinos, including a female who wandered off to search for food, and documented their roars, yawns, and movements. The photographer also spotted an impala antelope and a leopard cub playing in a tree. The reserve is Sir Richard Branson's private game reserve, and the photographer was rewarded with a unique opportunity to capture wildlife footage.

George Lucas is building an affordable housing complex on his property in the Bay Area, despite being met with resistance from his neighbors. The 52-acre development will provide 224 low-income homes, funded and designed by Lucasfilm Ltd, and funded by Lucas himself. The project is part of a larger effort by Lucas to expand his influence beyond filmmaking, and comes after he dropped plans for a Lucasfilm Ltd studio complex in 2012. His lawyers claim the project is not a form of retaliation, but rather a response to neighborhood opposition.

A great grey owl swooped on a tiny field mouse in Ontario, Canada, offering a bird's-eye view of the moment. The owl, with a five-foot wingspan, stalked its prey from snowy treetops and then launched a deadly attack, scooping up the mouse with its sharp claws. The owl's superior sense of hearing helped it catch its prey off guard, and its soft feathers allowed it to make a silent landing in the snow. The owl is a solitary hunter with an impressive wingspan and stealthy hunting style.

Manchester City defender Bacary Sagna has expressed no regrets about leaving Arsenal for Manchester City last summer, despite the team's underwhelming performance in the Premier League. He joined City in July, where they finished fourth in the league, while Arsenal secured the Premier League title. Sagna has played only 16 games for City this season, which has been described as "underwhelming" by both himself and the Premier League holders. However, he remains optimistic about the team's chances of returning to winning ways under manager Manuel Pellegrini.

David Cameron, the former Prime Minister, has been accused by Nigel Farage of secretly using hair dye to try to regain his youth. The incident came after a clash between the two during a televised leaders debate. Farage suggested that Cameron's decision to use hair dye is "jealousy" towards his own aging process. Cameron has previously used hair dye to try to maintain his youthful appearance, but Farage believes this is a vanity issue that affects many politicians.

A London council has refused to provide financial support for a World War II veteran, Robert Clark, to stay in his own home due to cost concerns. Clark, who survived the 1,000-mile death march and suffered severe anxiety and distress as a prisoner of war, has received an emergency grant from Help for Heroes to cover his living costs. The council wants to move him into a care home instead, citing budgetary constraints. Clark's family has launched a fundraising campaign to raise £5,000 to keep him at home, but the council claims it cannot afford to meet his needs.

FC Chernomorets Odessa is offering its players luxury houses near the sea as part of a plan to cover their salary debts. The club's financial struggles have led to the sale of some of its best players, with those remaining on board receiving luxury properties in exchange for reduced salaries. The offer includes houses valued at around £67,000, which will help alleviate the financial burden. The move comes as the club faces potential relegation and UEFA disqualification if it fails to pay off its outstanding debts.

A Lithuanian gangster, Kestutis Martuzevicius, has been accused of 22 crimes, including two murders, in his home country. He repeatedly stalled efforts to extradite him, claiming he was too depressed to leave Britain. Martuzevicius was admitted to a psychiatric hospital in 2019 and later returned to Belmarsh Prison, where he spent nearly five years before being released. The European Court of Human Rights ruled against his claim that extradition breached his human rights, citing that he had not been allowed to argue his illness during extradition proceedings.

A group of vigilante paedophile hunters, accused of posing as children online, have been accused of filming their attacks on men who agreed to meet them. The group, working in the North-West, allegedly tricked victims into believing they were meeting underage girls, only to beat them up and demand money to keep the footage secret. One teenager was attacked in Atherton, where he was tricked into meeting a 14-year-old girl he had met online, and another victim in Wigan was beaten up in Market Place after booking a hotel room and meeting a girl. The attackers, described as white men, used tactics such as filming and threatening violence to control their victims.

Real Madrid's Champions League starters returned to training after a break, with Isco and Alvaro Arbeloa among those present alongside regular first team players Pepe and Sami Khedira. The session was held at the Valdebebas complex, where Isco kept the ball from Fabio Coentrao during training. Pepe climbed the highest as the players who didn't start in the Champions League trained on Wednesday. Real will now face Atletico in next Wednesday's second leg, while also preparing for their La Liga match against Malaga on Saturday.

David Hibbitt, a 33-year-old man from Stoke-on-Trent, England, was diagnosed with advanced bowel cancer in July 2012. Despite receiving chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and surgery, he was told he had just 18 months to live. However, he refused to give up and instead turned to cannabis oil as a last resort, which helped him recover and eventually led to a full recovery. With the support of his fiancée, Heather, he went on to get married and start a new life.

President Barack Obama held up the shrinking Florida Everglades today as proof that climate change is real and threatening America's "national treasures" and economies, particularly those reliant on tourism. He emphasized the need for immediate action to address climate change, citing its impact on the Everglades and other natural areas like Glacier National Park and Joshua Tree National Park. Obama's visit to Everglades National Park marked a shift in tone, as he called for a collective effort to protect these ecosystems and ensure their preservation for future generations. His actions were met with applause from supporters, who saw him as a champion of environmental protection.

Javier Hernandez, 26, had a promising start to the season with five goals in his last six games, including a decisive strike against Atletico Madrid in the Champions League quarterfinal and two goals in a 4-2 win over Celta Vigo. However, Real Madrid failed to make a formal offer to buy him outright after the midnight deadline passed on Thursday night, leaving them to wait and see if other teams will come forward to sign him. Despite this setback, Hernandez remains a top target for several clubs, including West Ham, Southampton, Newcastle, and Lazio, who have expressed interest in signing him. His impressive form has led to speculation that he may be available for transfer, although the exact timeline for a move remains uncertain.

Bonnie Doll, a Brisbane-based gamer, has built a massive following on Twitch, playing Call Of Duty and gaining thousands of devotees. Born in Sweden, she moved to Australia in 2007 and started live streaming in 2014, initially playing Lara Croft, before transitioning to Call Of Duty. With over 45,000 followers on Twitch and nearly one million views, Bonnie earns a significant income from subscriptions and donations. She works from home, using her Xbox 1 and 360, and has a dedicated community of fans who support her financially and emotionally.
