Marion "Suge" Knight, a former rapper and founder of Death Row Records, has been hospitalized for an unspecified medical emergency after a judge ruled he will stand trial on murder and attempted-murder charges related to a hit-and-run incident involving two men. Knight, 49, was involved in a confrontation with Cle "Bone" Sloan, who was injured in the incident, and prosecutors allege he intentionally killed Sloan and tried to kill another man, Terry Carter, 55. Knight's parents saw him leave the courthouse after the judge's decision, and his lawyer, Matt Fletcher, expressed disappointment. The incident occurred in January, and authorities say Knight was taken into custody after a medical condition sent him to the hospital.

Bailey Murrill, a 7-year-old girl from Denton, Texas, was unexpectedly paralyzed for 11 days due to an unknown reason. Her favorite nurse, Becky Murrill, surprised her by getting up from her wheelchair and standing on her own after watching her regain feeling and movement in her legs. A video of the moment was captured by Becky's mother, showing the emotional reunion between Bailey and her nurse. The incident was shared online, garnering over 1 million views and sparking widespread praise for the nursing team.

Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, has agreed to be interviewed by Swedish prosecutors in London after previously agreeing to be held in the Ecuadorian Embassy in London to avoid extradition to Sweden, where prosecutors want to question him about alleged sex crimes committed in 2010. The interview will be conducted at the Ecuadorian Embassy, which is located in London, but Swedish prosecutors must first obtain permission from British and Ecuadorian authorities to do so. This decision comes after some of the alleged crimes may fall outside the statute of limitations in August 2015. Assange has denied the allegations against him and fears extradition to the US, where he could face the death penalty for publishing classified documents through WikiLeaks.

Pete Bennett, a former Big Brother star, has revealed that he is now homeless after struggling with drug addiction and personal issues. In a recent interview, he spoke candidly about his experiences, including starting an ill-fated relationship with fellow contestant Nikki Grahame and eventually marrying her, which ended in divorce. His struggles with Tourette's Syndrome added to his challenges, but he credits seeking help and entering therapy for turning his life around. Bennett has since attempted to revive his acting career, landing roles in several films and working towards making a name for himself in Hollywood.

Borussia Dortmund returned to winning ways with a comfortable 4-2-3-1 victory over relegation-threatened Paderborn at Signal Iduna Park, thanks in part to goals from Henrikh Mkhitaryan, Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang, and Shinji Kagawa. The win moved the team to eighth in the table, leaving them with a realistic chance of qualifying for Europe. The match saw a significant improvement in form for the team, who had struggled defensively earlier in the season. Dortmund's victory also marked a notable return to form for manager Jurgen Klopp, who announced his departure from the club in July.

A North Korean defector is launching hundreds of thousands of "propaganda balloons" carrying a Hollywood comedy film featuring Kim Jong Un, despite warnings from authorities that doing so could lead to violence and harm to himself and others. The defector claims the film portrays Kim as a vulnerable figure who is susceptible to assassination, and wants to expose the regime's propaganda efforts. The defector uses the balloons to send messages to North Koreans, despite the risk of detection and retaliation. Authorities have warned that the defector's actions could be seen as an act of terrorism, but he believes he must take a stand to bring truth to his country.

A new thermal protection case called Optimal has been developed by Israeli tech company Amited, which monitors the temperature of a phone and automatically adjusts its cooling system to prevent overheating. The case features two built-in micro-fans that blow heat away from the device or use resistance coils to warm it up if it gets too cold. The case includes temperature sensors, allowing it to analyze the phone's temperature and adjust accordingly. Optimal syncs with a smartphone via Bluetooth and continuously tracks temperature changes, revealing which apps are affecting the device's performance. The case is designed to work with various devices, including Apple, Samsung, Nexus, HTC, and Xperia phones, and is expected to launch in early April.

A Russian fishing vessel carrying 132 people went down in the Sea of Okhotsk after colliding with an obstacle, resulting in at least 54 deaths and 15 remaining missing. The Dalniy Vostok freezer trawler, a commercial vessel, was carrying mostly Russians but also had 78 foreign nationals on board. Over 60 people were rescued from the water, while more than 20 fishing vessels are searching for the missing crew members. The exact cause of the sinking is believed to be a collision with an obstacle, and the trawler has been deemed stable enough to support rescue efforts.

The food industry is flooded with numerous apps that cater to various needs, but only a few stand out as must-haves for food enthusiasts. Among the top picks include Where Chefs Eat (£10.99), which provides over 3,000 chef recommendations, Love Food Hate Waste (£0), which tracks food waste and suggests alternatives, and Femail, which recommends the best restaurants and dishes based on user preferences. These apps aim to simplify meal planning, budgeting, and grocery shopping, making it easier to enjoy delicious meals without the hassle. By choosing the right app, foodies can plan their meals, save money, and reduce food waste.

Frances Clarkson, 53, has been enjoying a family break in Barbados, showing off her tanned figure in a white bikini as she relaxes on the beach. She accessorized her look with a Help For Heroes wristband and swept her sun-bleached hair up into a butterfly clip. The 53-year-old has previously holidayed on the island with her estranged husband Jeremy Clarkson, whom she married in 1993.

Aldi, a discount supermarket chain, is under fire for failing to notify customers of a 0.5% credit card fee six months after promising to do so. The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) took action against the company after an investigation found that Aldi did not disclose the surcharge to customers. The company claims it puts up signs at stores and informs cashiers before payments, but critics argue that these measures are insufficient. Many customers are unaware of the surcharge, which applies to both credit and debit card transactions, regardless of whether they use a tap-and-go payment method.

A group of Russian bullion, valued at millions of pounds, was lost in the River Clyde due to a wartime blunder involving a former Irish Sea ferry converted into a battle cruiser. The bullion was loaded onto the HMS Ulster Queen in 1942 and was intended to pay the US for arms shipped to Russia during the Second World War. However, the case of the precious metals was lost overboard, and the incident remains unknown until recently uncovered through a secret diary kept by one of the Ulster Queen's engineers. The diary reveals that the crew attempted to unload the bullion onto a lighter, but it slipped and fell into the Clyde, resulting in a tragic accident.

Luis Suarez, the Uruguayan soccer player, admitted to biting Italy defender Giorgio Chiellini during the World Cup in Brazil, despite initially denying it. He received a four-month ban and was subsequently transferred to Barcelona from Liverpool for £75 million. After admitting to the incident, Suarez said "he didn't do it" when questioned by his wife Sofia, who revealed that she believed him until he finally confessed. Since his ban was lifted, Suarez has excelled with Barcelona, forming a successful partnership with teammates Lionel Messi and Neymar.

A 48-year-old man, Ranulfo Perez, was arrested in New York's Times Square for allegedly groping a 16-year-old girl who was showing off with her tour group. Perez was dressed as the Cookie Monster and was arrested after the girl alleged he touched her breasts without consent. Perez was released due to concerns that the girl couldn't identify him after the incident. This is the latest in a series of cases involving people dressed up as characters in Times Square, which has led to calls for regulation and licensing fees.

A 15-year-old son, Marc Wabafiyebazu, has been arrested for felony murder after a gunfight erupted during a drug deal in Miami. His 17-year-old brother, Jean, was shot and killed, while another teenager, Joshua Wright, was injured. The incident involved a group of Miami drug dealers, and both Marc and Joshua were armed with guns. The mother, Roxanne Dubé, was appointed as the Canadian Consul General in Miami, but only recently arrived in the city.

A 42-year-old urology specialist, Dr Omar Saadi Al-Atraqchi, was caught secretly filming men in the gym showers by cutting holes in Lynx shampoo bottles and hiding iPhones inside. He pleaded guilty to four counts of voyeurism and was fined £500, ordered to pay costs and a victim surcharge. Al-Atraqchi worked at Custom House Surgery in Newham, East London, and other local practices, and was banned from all Pure Gyms for life due to the incidents.

A former US Army enlistee, John T. Booker Jr., was arrested and charged with attempting to detonate a car bomb at Fort Riley military base in Kansas. Booker, who posted online about the thrill of dying in jihad, was found to have planned to use explosives to harm American soldiers. Two confidential informants helped him assemble the bomb, which was later revealed to be inert and non-explosive. Booker was arrested while driving near the base with a van containing the supposed bomb, and another man, Alexander E. Blair, was charged with failing to report a felony related to the plot.

Children who experience stressful events such as a death or illness in the family, divorce or separation, can be three times more likely to develop type 1 diabetes. A Swedish study analyzed over 10,000 families with children aged 2-14 without the condition, finding that 58 children were diagnosed with type 1 diabetes. Many of these children were among those who had experienced stressful events in their formative years. The research suggests that damaging events in childhood could affect the body's immune system, leading to an increased demand for insulin production. While the causes of type 1 diabetes are still unknown, genetic predisposition remains the most significant factor, with a 12-fold increase in risk for children with a family history of the condition.

A 15-year-old African American teenager, Jamar Nicholson, and his friend Jason Huerta, were shot by a police officer in the back while holding a toy gun in an alleyway in South Los Angeles. The incident occurred after the police officers mistook the toy gun for a real firearm, prompting the shooting. Nicholson and Huerta are suing the city of Los Angeles for $20 million, claiming that the use of racial profiling and discriminatory tactics led to the shooting.

A man was found asleep on the baggage reclaim conveyor at Domodedovo Airport in Russia, causing concern among passengers who were waiting to collect their luggage. Other passengers were more interested in finding their own bags than watching the sleeping man. This was not the first time an inebriated individual has been spotted relaxing on the baggage claim area. The incident was captured on camera and released as a warning to others to avoid doing so.

Cadbury is releasing a new super bar called the Dairy Milk Spectacular 7, featuring seven different fillings, including Dairy Milk Caramel, Dairy Milk Fruit & Nut, Dairy Milk Whole Nut, Dairy Milk Oreo, Dairy Milk Daim, and Dairy Milk Turkish. This marks a significant departure from traditional Cadbury products, with the seven-row bar being the first of its kind since 1921. The unique offering was created by combining research showing that British consumers prefer trying new flavors, particularly recommended by friends and family. The limited-edition bar will be available exclusively at select retailers, such as Tesco and Sainsbury's, until it sells out.

A 72-year-old former Nigerian military leader, Muhammadu Buhari, has won the presidential election, marking a significant moment in West African politics. His victory represents a shift towards maturity in the region after decades of instability and corruption. Buhari, who previously ruled as a harsh military leader, ran on an anti-corruption platform, suggesting that ordinary Nigerians have finally had enough of elite venality. The election marks a new era for Nigeria, which has struggled with poverty and corruption, and promises to tackle issues such as Boko Haram and corruption.

Dapper Laughs, the British comedian formerly known as Daniel O'Reilly, has arrived in Australia, documenting his journey from London to Sydney via Dubai and Melbourne. He met air hostesses and mocked airport cleaners during his trip, sparking controversy over his sexist comments. Despite apologizing for his past behavior, O'Reilly continued to use his "laddish" alter ego in social media posts, prompting criticism from comedians and fans. His TV show Dapper Laughs: On The Pull was cancelled by ITV after 60,000 people signed a petition against it.

Nine British Muslims caught trying to cross into Syria are no longer welcome in England and should find a new country to live, according to Labour's Simon Danczuk. The family, including Councillor Shakil Ahmed's son Waheed, were arrested in Turkey along with eight other relatives, including a 21-year-old son of a Labour councillor. They were apprehended trying to enter Syria and had been training to fight for ISIS, which shares a border with parts of Syria controlled by rebel factions linked to Al Qaeda and ISIS. The family is expected to return to the UK this week, with Labour MP Simon Danczuk stating that they would be forced to train as ISIS fighters if they were allowed to stay.

Avril Lavigne has revealed she has Lyme disease, a debilitating bacterial infection caused by a tick bite. The singer, who was between the Asian and South American world tours when she first developed symptoms, has struggled with the illness for months, experiencing symptoms such as headaches, joint pain, fatigue, and even dementia. A doctor initially suspected Lyme disease after Avril's symptoms persisted despite initial tests being negative, and she eventually received a diagnosis after undergoing multiple emergency room visits.

In August 2013, an Egyptian court sentenced 71 people to life in prison for their role in the burning of a Christian church in Kafr Hakim, Giza province. The Virgin Mary Church was torched and looted by a mob, who also targeted several other churches and homes, including St. George Church in Sohag and Prince Tadros Church in Fayoum. Two minors were sentenced to 10 years in prison and fined 10,000 Egyptian pounds. Most of those sentenced were tried in absentia, while others were already in prison. The attacks were linked to the Muslim Brotherhood, which backed former President Mohamed Morsy, who was ousted by the military in December 2012.

Two 18-year-old men, Sevdet Besim and two others, aged 19, have been charged with conspiring to commit terrorist acts in Australia after allegedly planning to attack a major national commemoration in Melbourne. The suspects, who were arrested over the weekend, had been identified as part of a counterterrorism operation. Authorities believe they were inspired by an ISIS-inspired plot, although the exact nature of their plans remains unclear. The suspects were targeting a ceremony on Anzac Day, which commemorates the end of World War I, and were described as "individuals acting alone".

Carles N'Zogbia wore a flamboyant outfit to Aston Villa training, which was ridiculed by Tim Sherwood, who described it as "the worst ever". N'Zogbia has featured regularly under Sherwood since his appointment in February, despite being known for his fondness for a gilet. The Irish midfielder posed in a colorful ensemble with sunglasses, making him look like a character from a cartoon. Sherwood took to Twitter to mock N'Zogbia's choice, calling it the "worst ever", while also referencing his own past experience of wearing a gilet during his time as Tottenham manager.

The British photographer Laura Stevens created the photo series "Another November", capturing the stages of grief following a breakup through staged photographs of women posing in various intimate settings. The series, inspired by her own painful break-up, explores the emotional and circumstantial stages of losing love, including feelings of pain, confusion, and loneliness. Each photograph is titled after the first name of the woman posing, creating a sense of intimacy and connection between the subjects. The series aims to represent and fictionalize personal situations, using cinematic drama and painterly aesthetics to convey the complexities of human emotions.

Andy Murray, the British No 1, is marrying his long-term girlfriend Kim Sears in his hometown of Dunblane on Saturday. He attended a wedding rehearsal at the cathedral where they met 10 years ago. The couple has been together for 10 years and have been preparing for their big day. A shortlist of potential assistants had been considered, including Swedish coach Jonas Bjorkman, who has been linked to Murray since earlier this year.

Pennsylvania police officer Lisa Mearkle is charged with criminal homicide in connection with the fatal shooting of David Kassick, who was unarmed and lying face down on the ground. Video footage of the incident, recorded by Mearkle's stun gun, shows her shooting two bullets into Kassick's back. The prosecution claims that Mearkle acted in self-defense, citing that Kassick reached into his jacket for a weapon. However, Mearkle's defense argues that she believed Kassick was reaching for a gun. The case is ongoing, with a preliminary hearing set for Monday and a possible waiver of the hearing scheduled for Tuesday.

Mick Schumacher, the 16-year-old son of seven-time Formula 1 World Champion Michael Schumacher, has returned to the racing circuit just weeks after being involved in a 100mph crash while testing in Formula 4 at the Oschersleben circuit in Germany. Mick Schumacher made his Formula 4 debut in March, where he was pictured accidentally driving through gravel during a pre-season test session. His father, Michael, also a seven-time Formula 1 World Champion, is recovering from a December 2013 ski accident and is expected to require time to fully recover. Mick Schumacher finished second in the world, European, and German kart championships last season.

A documentary series follows Bruce Jenner, 65, as he transitions into a woman in an eight-part E! show, sparking concerns among his children, particularly his sons Burt, Brandon, and Brody, who worry that the show may "de-class" his accomplishments. Bruce's eldest daughter Casey shares that she's excited to see her father's journey unfold, while his stepdaughter Kim Kardashian praises him as "spectacular" and says she's "by far the most accepting" of his transition. The show aims to educate and create empathy, with Bruce committing to being honest and open about his experiences.

The RSPCA is considering abandoning its policy of pursuing pointless fox hunting prosecutions after the collapse of the latest case. The charity has spent £22.5 million pursuing animal welfare prosecutions since 2005, but has no remaining cases under the Hunting Act. Critics argue that many hunters are prosecuted under the law for poaching, rather than fox hunting, and that the RSPCA should instead let the police handle such cases. The organization is reviewing its policy, which gives it the power to bring its own prosecutions, and is considering dropping the case against William Bryer, who was involved in a recent trial.

Former police officer Darren Stanton, now known as the UK's top human lie detector and body expert, claims that liars often stare, contrary to the old adage that they cannot look you in the eye. Stanton, who has a background in psychology, micro-expression training, and neuro-linguistic programming, uses his skills to detect deception through subtle body signals. On This Morning, Stanton revealed that liars often exhibit micro-expressions, such as a twitch in the mouth or a flicker of the eyelid, and that they tend to hold objects in their hands or use a "clutch" gesture to create a barrier between themselves and others. According to Stanton, liars often display these behaviors even when they are trying to deceive, making it easier to detect.

The article discusses the significance of Holy Week and Easter, a Christian holiday that marks the culmination of the Christian calendar. It highlights the importance of understanding the true meaning behind the celebrations, particularly the three days of Easter known as the Triduum - Good Friday, Holy Saturday, and Easter Sunday. These days commemorate the events leading up to the Crucifixion, the Last Supper, and the resurrection of Jesus Christ. The author argues that despite being a significant event in the Christian calendar, Holy Week and Easter are often misunderstood and overlooked, especially by non-Christian observers. The Triduum serves as a reminder of the transformative power of faith and the promise of eternal life, and its significance extends far beyond the confines of the Christian calendar.

A new app called Camoji makes creating and sending animated GIFs simple on smartphones, allowing users to record and share them via Facebook Messenger. Camoji is one of the first apps to integrate with Facebook's Messenger service, enabling users to add Instagram-style filters and share GIFs instantly. The app uses the Messenger platform to enable seamless interaction between users, with a "Reply" button that launches Camoji from the conversation. With over 600 million monthly active users, Camoji aims to transform Facebook's messaging service into a more interactive and expressive platform, potentially competing with traditional email and messaging apps like Twitter and Snapchat.

Labour leader Ed Miliband has warned that if elected, his party would implement measures to reduce immigration, including increasing penalties for employers who exploit migrant workers and requiring migrants to learn English. This would include a new unit within the Home Office to tackle exploitation and a crackdown on illegal working. However, Conservative immigration minister James Brokenshire dismissed these proposals, saying they would not help control immigration. Labour leader Ed Miliband admitted that in the past his party had been "too timid" about promoting a shared language among communities, but emphasized the importance of speaking English in key services like the NHS.

Four terrified puppies strapped in a cage to the roof of a van were rescued after dozens of concerned drivers called 911 and police pulled over the car in Akron, Ohio, during a 300-mile journey from Nova, Ohio to Pennsylvania. Wendell Steiner, his wife, and their four children were stopped by police due to a report of a dog being transported on top of a moving vehicle. Mitt Romney, the former US president, was also involved, having driven for 12 hours with his Irish Setter Seamus on his car in 1983. The puppies belonged to Steiner's father and were taken to a local veterinarian hospital for examination and adoption.

Louis Smith will represent Great Britain for the first time since his double Olympic medal-winning performance at London 2012 as he competes in the European Championships. He was previously an Olympic medalist, winning silver and bronze in pommel horse and team bronze at the London Games. Smith, a reigning pommel horse champion, joins a talented group of athletes, including Max Whitlock, Kristian Thomas, Sam Oldham, and Daniel Purvis, to compete in the individual all-around and apparatus events. The European Championships take place in Montpellier from April 15 to 19, featuring only individual events.

A New York taxi driver Mohammed Dahbi was ordered to pay a $10,000 fine to a lesbian couple after he discriminated against them by telling them to stop kissing in the back of his cab. Dahbi had warned them to "keep that behavior for the bedroom" if they didn't comply, but when they refused, he became aggressive and verbally abusive, calling them derogatory names. The incident occurred on September 18, 2011, when Dahbi picked up actress Kassie Thornton and her TV executive partner Christy Spitzer from Columbus Circle to Sunset Park in Brooklyn. After getting out of the cab, Dahbi continued to harass them, calling them insults and threatening to throw them out.

Jonas Gutierrez was dropped from Newcastle's starting lineup after a fallout with head coach John Carver, who stated that he wanted to "move on" from their dispute. The Argentinian midfielder was not named in the substitutes' list for Sunday's 3-1 defeat at Spurs, despite being available to play. Sources close to Gutierrez claim he was axed due to selection reasons, while Carver denied any disciplinary issues. Despite being released at the end of the season, Gutierrez will not be offered a new deal by Newcastle.

ISIS militants, affiliated with Al Qaeda, infiltrated the Yarmouk refugee camp in Damascus, Syria, and took control of large parts of the camp following clashes with Palestinian groups. The militants, who control large swaths of territory in northern Syria, used the camp as a base to threaten the capital and challenge President Bashar Assad. The militants murdered a blindfolded and bound couple in front of a crowd, allegedly accusing them of having sex without being married, and threw stones at them before killing them. The incident occurred during heavy clashes between government forces and rebels in the area.

Amanda Peake Glover, a devoted youth ministry teacher and choir singer, died suddenly after completing the Palmetto Half Marathon in South Carolina. She was a fitness enthusiast who had recently completed a full marathon with her brother and owned a fitness center. Her husband, Benji, was reportedly the most shocked by her death, as he had been behind her in the previous year's Palmetto Half Marathon. The circumstances surrounding her death remain unclear, but it appears to have been a tragic coincidence.

Labour's shadow chancellor, Ed Balls, was left stumped by a basic maths question while giving a speech in Leeds. The question was about seven times six, which he answered incorrectly before laughing nervously and saying "the answer is 42". This came after he admitted to relying on his mother-in-law for help with maths.

Alastair Cook and Jonathan Trott are among six English pairs to have scored over 100 runs together on multiple occasions, with Cook and Strauss (2006-12), Cook and Pietersen (2006-13), Bell and Pietersen (2005-14), Cook and Trott (2009-15), and Trott and Vaughan (2000-05) also notable partnerships. Their most recent stand came in Test cricket for over two years, since March 2013 when Cook and Nick Compton scored an impressive 231 against New Zealand. Meanwhile, West Indies bowler Shannon Gabriel continued his impressive form, picking up where he left off after reaching 93mph on Wednesday.

New York City skin clinic Skin Laundry's popular laser treatment promises to tighten skin and improve complexion, but requires clients to sign a waiver releasing personal information to a funeral director and coroner. The treatment involves a two-step process, including a deep cleanse, gel application, and laser therapy, lasting around 10 minutes. Clients must sign an 8-page contract, which includes warnings about potential risks such as blistering, itching, and infection. Despite concerns, the treatment has gained popularity among clients, with many reporting improvements in wrinkles, acne, and scarring.

Floyd Mayweather and Manny Pacquiao's eagerly-anticipated weight-in tickets for their upcoming fight have sold out within minutes on Friday evening, with over 10,000 tickets available. The MGM Resorts Box Office was overwhelmed with calls, and tickets for the pair's face-off on May 1, 24 hours before their mega-fight in Las Vegas, went on sale from the MGM property box offices on Friday at 3pm. Tickets for the fight, which is being promoted by Mayweather Promotions and Pacquiao's promoter Bob Arum, were initially priced from $1,500 to $7,500 per seat. However, some super-ringside tickets costing $10,000 were not released for public sale, with reports suggesting they could fetch upwards of $200,000 on the black market.

Victoria's Secret Angel Alessandra Ambrosio is recovering at UCLA Hospital in Los Angeles following a'medical procedure' for 'constant headaches'. She was seen partying at the Coachella festival in California, where she suffered from constant headaches despite seeming perfectly healthy. Ambrosio had booked the appointment two weeks prior to the event. Her fiancé Jamie Mazur was present during the festival, which included appearances by other celebrities such as Kendall Jenner and Vance Joy.

A rowing team from Oxford University Women's Boat Race were rescued from the Thames by the Royal National Lifeboat Institution (RNLI) after being swept away by choppy waters while training for the Boat Race. The team, along with their cox, were pulled to safety by Chiswick RNLI station crew. The incident occurred during training sessions on the Thames, where strong winds created three successive waves that overwhelmed the boat's riggers, causing flooding. The RNLI responded quickly to assist the team, recovering the sunken boat and returning it to Oxford's base. The Oxford crew will now prepare for the Boat Race on April 11, which also features the men's competition.

Lucas Moura has expressed admiration for Lionel Messi, calling him "the best player in the world" and stating that he is "obsessed" with the Argentine forward's playing style. The Paris Saint-Germain playmaker singled out Messi as his idol, praising his exceptional skills and technique. Moura believes Messi is the greatest player of all time, despite being from different countries, and considers them to be rivals. He also acknowledged that this creates an intense atmosphere during matches between Brazil and Argentina. With the two teams set to face each other in the Champions League, Moura emphasized that they must be realistic about their chances of success.

Zayn Malik's relationship with Little Mix singer Perrie Edwards has come under scrutiny due to repeated cheating allegations. The 22-year-old was accused of cheating on his fiancée during a holiday in Thailand, with Swedish model Martina Olsson claiming they had sex while he was away. This is not the first time Zayn has been accused of cheating, with previous allegations coming from Courtney Webb and Lauren Richardson. Zayn has denied the allegations, tweeting that he loves Perrie and that the situation is "OK". However, Perrie is reportedly still committed to him, despite the ongoing rumors.

Politicians in Arkansas and Indiana recently passed "religious freedom" bills, which sparked widespread outrage and confusion among business owners and organizations, including companies like Marriott International, which launched a marketing campaign to attract LGBTQ+ travelers. The backlash highlights the shift in public opinion, with 72% of millennials believing same-sex couples should have equal rights, and 90% of youths aged 14-24 agreeing that making their communities less biased is essential. This marks a significant departure from the past, when socially conservative evangelicals and pro-business interests were powerful allies against government regulations and social welfare programs. Businesses that fail to address anti-gay bias face financial risks, and media-savvy millennials are leading the charge to spread awareness and mobilize against discrimination.

Jake Hall scored a vital goal for Boston United, impressing his on-screen girlfriend Chloe Lewis in the stands. She was seen smiling and cheering from York Street, while TOWIE star James 'Arg' Argent was also in attendance. Hall scored two goals for the non-league team, putting a smile on Lewis's face. Hall's friend James 'Arg' Argent joined in the celebrations, and semi-professional footballer Hall returned to Boston United after playing for the team last season.

A group of foreign volunteers, including Americans, are volunteering to fight alongside Kurdish forces in Iraq and Syria to combat ISIS. These individuals, often referred to as foreign fighters, are part of a larger effort to provide training and support to local militias, such as the Peshmerga, in the region. Despite initial skepticism, many of these volunteers believe that their skills and experience can make a positive impact in the fight against ISIS. However, others, including the Peshmerga, have expressed concerns about accepting foreign fighters due to potential sectarian divisions and the perception that they may be seen as outsiders.

A romantic love story blossomed amidst the horrors of a Nazi concentration camp during World War II, between a British soldier, Sergeant Norman Turgel, and a teenage Polish girl, Gena, who was only 20 years old. Despite being stranded in the camp, they found solace in each other's company, thanks to the kindness of British Commander Major Leonard Berney. Their love was sparked by the generosity and compassion shown by Major Berney towards both soldiers and prisoners, allowing them to form a strong bond despite the dire circumstances. After being liberated by British forces in 1945, they married and started a family, but tragically, Norman passed away two months shy of their 51st wedding anniversary.

In Gorkha, Nepal, a town near the epicenter of the devastating earthquake, medical teams are treating injured individuals in challenging conditions. The town has seen only 10 collapsed or severely damaged houses, despite being surrounded by landslides. The hospital, which is ill-equipped to handle the influx of patients, provides basic treatment and transfers those in need to larger hospitals in other districts or Kathmandu. A Swiss Humanitarian Aid Unit and International Search and Rescue Germany provide assistance, working closely with local staff to save lives.

In Indonesia, President Joko Widodo has maintained a tough stance on drug smugglers since taking office in October, casting a negative impact on two Australian drug smugglers, part of the so-called "Bali Nine". The group, which included Andrew Chan and Myuran Sukumaran, were arrested after receiving a tip from Australian Federal Police and were sentenced to life in prison for their role in a failed heroin smuggling plot. The Bali Nine members, including Andrew Chan and Myuran Sukumaran, were arrested in April and had their sentences reduced or reinstated over the years due to claims of false accusations. The Indonesian government rejected the appeals of Chan and Sukumaran, citing extensive rehabilitation efforts, and Foreign Minister Julie Bishop expressed disappointment in the decision.

A new paper suggests that the Earth may have collided with a body similar to the planet Mercury, potentially explaining the similarities between the two planets' cores and compositions. This collision could have generated heat, driving the formation of Earth's core and producing radioactive elements necessary for its dynamo. The discovery challenges the traditional understanding of Earth's formation, which typically involves the accumulation of smaller asteroid and planetary bodies. Researchers propose that a Mars-sized body struck the young Earth around 4.5 billion years ago, producing a similar composition to Mercury and contributing to the moon's formation.

Daniel Ricciardo practices with a martial artist at Guyi Garden ahead of the Chinese Grand Prix, where he aims to find a formula to kick-start his and the team's season after a slow start to the year. Despite struggling to keep up with Mercedes, Red Bull still counts on Ricciardo to score points. The team fell even further back in the standings this season, with rivals Sebastian Vettel and Nico Rosberg pushing Lewis Hamilton and Nico Rosberg at the sharp end of the grid. With a focus on discipline, Ricciardo has picked up some new skills, which may help him cope with the challenges ahead.

A drone carrying small traces of radioactive material landed on the roof of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's office in protest against the government's nuclear energy plans. The drone, estimated to be 4 cm wide, was spotted by a member of the Prime Minister's staff and contained a small amount of radioactive caesium. Police and bomb squad responded, and the drone was later determined to be harmless to humans. The incident occurred while Prime Minister Abe was away in Indonesia attending a conference.

The Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS) is a complex and multifaceted terrorist organization that poses a significant threat to global security. Despite being tried to scare and confuse, the group's true intentions are rooted in a desire for power and control, driven by a lust for dominance. ISIS presents itself as a global organization, but its success lies in its ability to exploit local grievances and recruit fighters from various regions, particularly in Iraq and Syria. The group's ultimate goal appears to be building a caliphate in Iraq and Syria, with the US being its primary target.

The UK's leaders, including Prime Minister David Cameron and Deputy Leader Nick Clegg, appeared together on the Gogglebox sofa during a televised debate, sparking memes referencing their positions. Labour leader Ed Miliband was superimposed over London rapper Plan B, while Nicola Sturgeon posed with a skeptical face alongside the SNP leader. The debate itself featured a mix of humorous moments, including a reference to the "fight" between Miliband and Farage, and a nod to the iconic Titanic movie. The event was notable for its unusual lineup, which included appearances by Farage, Bennett, and Wood, who all seemed to have taken a different approach to the debate.

Manchester City fans were ejected from Old Trafford for allegedly mocking the Munich Air Disaster during a 4-2 derby defeat by Manchester United. A handful of Manchester City fans were ejected for mocking the Munich Disaster, while others were accused of performing a similar gesture. The incident occurred during a 4-2 win for Manchester United, with Ashley Young scoring the winning goal. Former Manchester City goalkeeper Frank Swift was among those killed in the crash that killed 23 people in 1958. Eight people were arrested at the match, with three further arrests made for public order and disorderly conduct.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini has hinted that the club may look to cherry-pick the best youngsters from their top-flight rivals to fill gaps in their first-team squad due to concerns over the readiness of their academy players. The current crop of homegrown players, including James Milner, Frank Lampard, and Joe Hart, are not considered ready for the first team. Pellegrini's comments may lead to the purchase of English players like Raheem Sterling or Ross Barkley to meet the required quota. The lack of suitable candidates from Patrick Vieira's academy means City will rely on buying in the bulk of their quota, potentially attracting Arsenal's Jack Wilshere and Everton's Ross Barkley.

A heavily pregnant Jehovah's Witness, Jenny-Lee, refused to receive a blood transfusion during her pregnancy despite medical advice to allow her to have a caesarean section and undergo chemotherapy. As a result, her baby, Aroura, died in utero three days after birth, and later suffered a fatal stroke and multi-organ failure. The family defends Jenny-Lee's decision, stating that she prioritized her unborn child above her own life. The incident highlights the controversy surrounding Jehovah's Witnesses' stance on blood transfusions, which they believe command them to abstain from consuming blood.

A Muslim father, Mohammad Liaqat, stormed into a Catholic school, Mount Carmel Roman Catholic High School in Accrington, and launched a racist tirade against teachers after two teenage pupils were banned from growing beards due to a school rule. Despite being told they could keep their facial hair for religious reasons, Liaqat objected to the policy and assaulted the headteacher, Xavier Bowers, before being arrested and charged with assault. The incident occurred when 14-year-old boys were told they couldn't keep their beards, prompting Liaqat to launch a verbal attack on the school staff, including racial abuse and insults. Liaqat also assaulted the headteacher at another school, St Oswald's Primary, where he was later remanded in custody and set to face sentencing in June.

Chinese police have arrested over 133,000 people and seized 43.3 tons of illegal narcotics during a six-month anti-drug campaign, the country's Ministry of Public Security announced. Authorities also handled 115,000 drug-related crimes, including robbery and drug use, and 606,000 cases of drug trafficking. Drug trafficking groups have suffered a significant blow, but the police have also faced a high cost, with nine police officers killed and 657 injured. A three-month online campaign targeted internet-related drug crimes, resulting in the arrest of several celebrities, including Jaycee Chan, son of Jackie Chan.

A new species of glass frog, Hyalinobatrachium dianae, has been discovered in eastern Costa Rica with translucent skin that allows its internal organs to be visible. The frog, named after its discoverer Brian Kubicki, has a bright green back and translucent abdomen, distinguishing it from other glass frogs. The frog's unique appearance includes a distinctive call, described as a "metallic whistle-like note", which is different from other glass frogs. The discovery was made in the mountains of Heredia and Limon provinces, and researchers believe the frog's ability to see its internal organs makes it distinct from other glass frogs.

The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge have moved back to Kensington Palace to prepare for the imminent birth of their new baby. Prince William, who is set to take two weeks' statutory paternity leave, will spend the next six weeks with his wife Kate at the Lindo Wing, where she will give birth. Meanwhile, Prince Harry will return to the UK to watch the London Marathon and potentially meet his future niece or nephew. Prince William's training with the East Anglia Air Ambulance has been completed ahead of schedule, allowing him to join Kate at the hospital.

A 67-year-old French native, Maurice Thibaux, stormed onto the catwalk at Sydney's Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week while fashion designer Kym Ellery was taking her bow, claiming the noise was similar to a jumbo jet taking off. The incident occurred during an opening show at the Carriageworks in Eveleigh, Sydney's inner city. Thibaux was escorted off the catwalk by security guards after causing a disturbance. The noise was described as "way too loud" by eyewitnesses, who also reported that the show's hardcore electronic music was disrupting their sleep.

FBI agents have been required to take compulsory fitness tests due to concerns over expanding waistlines and lack of mobility among 135,000 agents. The tests include running a mile in 12.5 minutes and sprinting 300 meters in 59 seconds, with those who fail facing disciplinary action. The goal is to improve the overall fitness of the force, which has seen a decline in recent years. The introduction of the tests follows a shift in focus from traditional law enforcement activities to counter-terrorism efforts.

A volcano in Chile that has lain dormant for over 40 years has suddenly erupted, forcing thousands of people to flee their homes due to a thick plume of ash and smoke. Volcano Calbuco, considered one of Chile's three most dangerous volcanoes, erupted unexpectedly, sparking panic and destruction in the surrounding areas. The eruption was triggered by magma forcing its way to the surface, resulting in a massive explosion that sent ash and lava several kilometers into the air.

Prime Minister David Cameron defended the Church of England against accusations of dismissing welfare claimants and promoting condescending attitudes towards those in need. In an Easter message to Christians, he argued that the Coalition had tried to "lift people up" through policies such as making work pay and encouraging responsibility. The Church published a guide to how Christians should approach the General Election, but critics saw it as targeting specific groups rather than addressing the root causes of poverty. The Prime Minister acknowledged that the Church's views may not align with his own, stating that the values of compassion, forgiveness, and hard work are central to the Christian faith.

Protesters in Baltimore are seeking answers about the circumstances surrounding Freddie Gray's death during a police chase on April 12, which they claim was excessive force. The incident began when Gray ran away from police, prompting a pursuit that lasted around 30 minutes, during which he was cuffed and transported in a wagon. The police department has released limited information about the events, sparking outrage among protesters, who argue that the use of force was unjustified. The protests have turned violent, with demonstrators clashing with police, and several officers have been suspended with pay.

A 33-year-old airport worker, Brandon Afoa, was awarded $40 million in compensation after a freak runway accident at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport left him paralyzed from the waist down. The incident occurred on December 26, 2007, when Afoa's tug failed, causing him to crash into a luggage lift while working at the airport. Afoa sued the Port of Seattle, claiming the company failed to maintain a safe workplace. The state supreme court ultimately ruled in favor of Afoa, finding the airport had a duty to provide a safe working environment. A jury awarded Afoa $40 million, with 25% attributed to the Port of Seattle.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal is set to discuss his team with Sir Alex Ferguson, who has expressed a tongue-in-cheek hope that he will pay, but ultimately hopes for genuine progress. The current Manchester United manager is preparing for a crucial match against Aston Villa, which could see them leapfrog Manchester City into second place. A win over Villa would give United a significant boost, but they face stiff competition from Liverpool, who defeated their rivals 13 days prior. The pressure is mounting on United to avoid finishing behind City, who are struggling after losing to Arsenal.

A passenger flying from Newcastle Airport to Gatwick was pulled aside at security after staff thought his pease pudding was Semtex, a plastic explosive. The passenger, a part-time actor, had six £1.80 tubs of traditional pease pudding in his hand luggage, which included several Greggs pies. Security staff initially thought the pudding was Semtex due to its resemblance to the container markings, but the passenger admitted he was carrying the pudding and offered to let them taste it to prove it wasn't. This incident is not the first time unusual items have been picked up by airport security scanners.

The West Indies cricket team has been named for the first Test match against England, which begins in Antigua on Monday. The uncapped duo of Shai Hope and Carlos Brathwaite have been included in the 14-man squad, while Jason Holder takes his place as one-day captain. Sheldon Cottrell, Miguel Cummins, Shane Dowrich, and Veerasammy Permaul were among those dropped from the initial training camp. The remaining players include Denesh Ramdin, who will lead the team for the three-match series, and 21-year-old wicketkeeper-batsman Shai Hope and pace bowler Carlos Brathwaite.

A 27-year-old sex trade worker, Rejean Hermel Perron, has been accused of holding a woman captive for five days and subjecting her to multiple sexual assaults. A dog walker, Peter Hamilton, intervened and freed the woman, who was bound by handcuffs and naked from the waist down. Perron was arrested and charged with various crimes, including sexual assault with a weapon, kidnapping, forcible confinement, and assault. The incident occurred in Toronto, Canada, and police believe there may be additional victims who have yet to come forward.

Sergio Garcia is focusing on winning his first PGA Tour title since 2012 at this week's Shell Houston Open, despite the Masters being just around the corner. His goal is to replicate the conditions of the tournament, which included playing in front of a large crowd and competing against strong competition. Garcia played out of the trees by the 11th hole at Augusta in 2013, where he won alongside Rickie Fowler. He is confident about his chances, having finished third last year but now aims to end his victory drought. With Rory McIlroy seeking a third major victory in succession, Garcia believes his focus should remain on winning the tournament rather than worrying about the Masters.

In Nepal, a video shoot for an internet comedy series took a serious turn when a magnitude-7.8 earthquake struck, prompting the Nepali Pranksters to continue filming despite the danger. The team shot footage of the disaster unfolding in the city of Lalitpur, which is home to Nepal's famed Central Zoo. The Pranksters captured scenes of destruction, heroism, and chaos, showcasing people's reactions to various "pranks" challenging cultural norms. Despite the risks, they filmed for 18 minutes before realizing the severity of the situation and stopping production.

Max Azria's 30,000 sq ft Los Angeles mansion, featuring a two-story-tall chandelier and 22 bathrooms, is now on the market with a $85 million price tag. Spread across three acres in Holmby Hills, the mansion boasts a sprawling layout, including a private tennis court, movie theater, and multiple gardens. Architect Paul Williams built the original home in 1939 for Old Hollywood stars, and it was later renovated by Max and Lubov Azria, who added luxury features such as a Moroccan-style bathhouse and a spa. The couple's home, dubbed Maison du Solei, is part of the Platinum Triangle neighborhood and offers breathtaking views of Beverly Hills and Bel Air.

A 50-year-old woman, Mei Ru, and her husband, Song Ming, 53, were on their way home from shopping in Fuzhou, Fujian province, China, when they were involved in a fatal accident. The incident occurred when Mei Ru's car was reversing while her husband climbed out of the passenger door, causing him to knock her down before being backed over by the car. The couple was rushed to the hospital, where doctors battled to save Song's life, but he ultimately died from massive internal bleeding and broken ribs. Mei Ru was also injured and hospitalized for shock.

NBC News has retracted its previous account of how chief foreign correspondent Richard Engel was kidnapped in Syria, stating that he was likely taken by Sunni rebels who tried to convince their victims they were government militants. The 2012 kidnapping, which saw Engel held for five days and expected to be killed, was carried out by forces associated with President Bashar-al-Assad. However, Engel claims that the men who took him were in fact a Sunni group who had tried to convince their victims that they were Shi-ite rebels affiliated to the Government.

Lidia Quilligana, a nanny from Connecticut, was arrested and charged with first-degree assault of a child under 10 years old and criminal mischief after a video surfaced showing her allegedly beating a 3-year-old girl. The incident occurred when the girl's family installed a nanny cam to monitor her care, which captured footage of Quilligana choking and burning the girl's legs, arms, and hands on a hot stove while screaming in pain. Quilligana claims she knew she was being filmed and denies the allegations. Four other families have come forward to support her, stating that she has a good track record and has never had any problems with children before.

A little girl named Anya Brodie asked Michelle Obama her age during a question and answer session at the White House, asking "I'm 51," which Michelle Obama replied with "Say that again!" A flattered Obama then asked Brodie to repeat the compliment, prompting Brodie to say "You're too young for a 51-year-old!" Michelle Obama was touched by the comment and invited Brodie onto the stage to give her a hug, where they shared a warm and affectionate moment together.

Philip Garrod, a 43-year-old paramedic, was caught speeding on his powerful Suzuki motorbike while on duty with the Welsh Ambulance Service. He pleaded guilty to speeding and was fined £650 with six points for doing 105mph in a 60mph zone. However, he initially lied about the incident, claiming it was a genuine emergency call to avoid a driving ban. An investigation revealed that there was no record of such a call, prompting a misconduct hearing which found that Garrod's actions fell below the standard expected of a registered healthcare professional.

Vin Los, a 24-year-old Canadian model, gained notoriety after covering his entire body in Sharpie-like tattoos, earning him a lucrative career as a model despite initial skepticism about its feasibility. Despite having only 24 tattoos, including those on his face, neck, arms, and chest, Vin has landed a campaign for underwear brand Garçon Model and has become a social media sensation. His unique look makes him a "myth" and "mystery," inspiring fans to learn more about his story and his passion for pop culture.

Sir Stirling Moss, widely regarded as the greatest all-round racer of his generation, has revealed his unusual daily routine at 85, which includes 77 press-ups and half a bottle of Chardonnay per day. After winning 212 races over 14 years, he has traded in his high-octane vehicles for a tiny electric car with a top speed of 50mph. A new documentary reunited him with his former racing partner, the Austin-Healey Sprite, which he used as a training car before a devastating crash at Goodwood in 1962. Now, he drives a Renault Twizy, a low-speed electric car that allows him to enjoy the freedom of the open road without putting strain on his body.

Taylor Lynn Fast, 21, was arrested after her 17-month-old daughter Layla was found beaten to death at their home. The cause of death is believed to be related to a spider bite, according to police. Layla had severe injuries, including facial and neck trauma, and was pronounced dead shortly after arrival at the hospital. Her 3-year-old son was also found at the house with similar injuries.

An officer with the Ocala Police Department, Jared Forsyth, 33, was accidentally shot by a coworker during firearms training at a gun range at the Lowell Correctional Institution. Forsyth, who had been a member of the department since 2012, was wearing a bulletproof vest but the round entered through his arm and went through his chest, killing him. He was rushed to Ocala Regional Medical Center in critical condition and took into surgery, where he later died. The incident is being investigated by the Florida Department of Law Enforcement.

The church has been the subject of controversy over the years due to allegations of child abuse linked to the church's former pastor, Ronald Pickering.

A 20-year-old man from Cardiff, Shaquille Omar Hallisey, was sentenced to four years in prison for attacking a 38-year-old man, Matthew Leeke, with a bottle, leaving him with a fractured skull. Hallisey pleaded guilty to wounding with intent to cause grievous bodily harm and was found to have been the victim of violence himself when younger. The incident occurred in public, where Hallisey struck Leeke with a bottle, causing serious injuries. Hallisey's guilty plea was seen as brave, but ultimately led to his conviction. He will serve four years in prison for his actions.

A new study reveals that pets spend a staggering 21 hours a week watching TV, with many owning multiple TVs at home and some pets preferring programs featuring other animals. The average pet watches around 3 hours a day, with 34% of pet owners saying their pets watch 3 hours a day while left home alone. Pigs are particularly fond of TV, with one owner letting their pet watch 28 hours a week. This trend extends to dogs, who watch an average of 21 hours a week, and even goldfish, which watch an impressive 28 hours a week.

Carl Froch is expected to return to the ring after a year-long absence due to injury, with three potential fights lined up in the next two months. His next opponent is James DeGale, who won a thrilling victory over Anthony Dirrell, and another contender is Anthony Dirrell himself, although Froch may prefer a rematch with Paul Smith. Froch's team has expressed interest in a fight against DeGale, while Anthony Frampton's team has rejected an offer to fight Froch.

A 9-year-old girl named Annabel Beam fell 30ft headfirst into a hollow tree while playing outside with her sisters. Her mother, Christy Wilson Beam, reported that Annabel claimed to have fallen into a state of unconsciousness and later miraculously recovered from a severe head injury, despite being rushed to the hospital with significant injuries. Annabel's mother believes that her daughter's experience was a spiritual encounter with Jesus, and that she believes she visited Heaven. After recovering from her injuries, Annabel began experiencing vivid dreams and visions, including seeing a guardian angel and a deceased relative, Mimi, who had passed away in 2010.

Three cars were broken into and damaged within the Richard Dunn Sports Centre car park, situated opposite the Provident Stadium, Odsal, after a recent incident involving the Bradford Bulls. The team has launched an investigation into reports of vandalism during their Ladbrokes Challenge Cup fifth-round defeat by Hull KR. The Bulls are appealing for witnesses and are working closely with authorities to identify those responsible. Since Monday morning, similar incidents have also been reported in local car parks. To address these issues, the team is taking steps to improve security measures in the car park.

A mid-air altercation over legroom on a flight from London Heathrow to Oman resulted in a brawl after one passenger allegedly attacked another with a shoe. The fight broke out on Oman Air flight 102 to Muscat after one man moved seats due to the plane not being full. Passengers intervened after the argument escalated into a full-blown fight on board. The incident occurred on a flight departing London Heathrow at 9:30 pm, with the plane landing safely at Muscat International Airport.

A US Navy helicopter was flown within 50 yards of an Iranian armed aircraft over the Persian Gulf, prompting concerns about Iranian control of local forces. The incident occurred while US and international leaders met in Switzerland to discuss a nuclear deal with Iran. Iranian observation aircraft typically operate in the region, but this particular incident raised questions about their professionalism. The US military is considering a potential protest against Iran due to the close proximity of the US helicopter.

A survey conducted by Frontline Spot On found that the "perfect" dog would have the body of a Border Collie, the ears of a King Charles Spaniel, and the tail of an Irish Setter. This combination of characteristics was favored by 2,000 pet owners, with 41% preferring small dogs that don't take up much space. In contrast, 41% of Londoners chose small dogs, while 19% preferred larger dogs like Great Danes. The survey also revealed that 30% of respondents valued the mid-range bark of a Labrador, while 24% preferred the soft fluffy ears of a King Charles Spaniel.

Scottish soldiers, Jason Collins, 22, and Shaun Smith, 25, were convicted of assaulting a civilian, James Wormald, 25, after a drunken attack in April. Collins, a Welsh Guardsman, was sentenced to 12 months' probation and ordered to complete 80 hours of unpaid work, while Smith was given a 12-month suspended sentence. The court described the attack as "shocking" and "inexcusable", with CCTV footage showing Collins kicking and punching Wormald repeatedly.

Leicester City boss Nigel Pearson has defended his former West Ham manager Sam Allardyce after criticizing him for his involvement in several controversies, including grabbing Crystal Palace midfielder James McArthur by the throat and losing his cool with a reporter during a press conference. Despite these incidents, Allardyce praises Pearson for being "his own man" and believes he has done an "unbelievable job". The two managers will reunite when West Ham face Leicester at the King Power Stadium on Saturday, where they will attempt to end a goal-drought for Leicester.

Eighteen-month-old twins, Silas and Eli Keslar, drowned after their mother, Alexis Keslar, tried to fend off a bee while walking with them on a canal in Yuma, Arizona. The stroller they were in rolled away into the canal, and despite trying to rescue them, the current swept it away. Police say the path along Yuma canals can be hazardous due to its steep sides, depth, and strong currents. The incident highlights the dangers of ignoring safety precautions when navigating these areas.

A 29-year-old man from Hawthorne, Nevada, suffered severe burns in a childhood accident at the age of six, resulting in 70% of his body being damaged. Despite facing cruel taunts from bullies due to his appearance, he refused to let fear take over his life and instead chose to become a firefighter. After undergoing 58 operations, he persevered and eventually became a firefighter, overcoming his traumatic experiences to help others. Now, he runs a foundation to support children with burns, providing funding for programs that offer firefighting experience.

A fund-raising drive to help one of Britain's oldest war veterans, Robert Clark, stay in his own home after a London council refused to pay for his ongoing care has reached £10,000 in just four days. Despite having already raised £10,000, the council has now increased its funding to £15,000, but still refuses to provide a live-in carer due to budget constraints. The pensioner, who has lived in his home for over 50 years, is anxious about leaving his familiar surroundings and is worried about being sent to a care home. A fund-raising campaign launched by the armed forces charity Help for Heroes aims to raise additional funds to support Mr Clark's care.

A Conservative building in Scotland's capital city, Aberdeen, has been sprayed with graffiti by "nationalists", according to a local councillor. The vandalism includes a swastika and the word "scum" spray-painted on the window of the offices, as well as a "Q" symbol added to the front door, which some interpret as a reference to quisling, a term for someone who collaborates with an enemy. This incident comes six months after similar incidents targeting Labour offices and polling stations in the lead-up to the Scottish Referendum. Police Scotland is investigating the matter.

Lucas Matthysse won a majority decision against Ruslan Provodnikov in a 12-round super lightweight bout, landing the majority of the punches in the first round and opening a cut near Provodnikov's left eye early in the second. Provodnikov (24-3) put Matthysse on the ropes late in the third round and landed two hard right hook-left hook combos in the fourth before Matthysse regained control in the fifth. Despite Provodnikov's efforts, Matthysse ultimately won by majority decision, scoring 114-114 from Don Ackerman. Provodnikov admitted that Matthysse was better than him on the day, while Matthysse expressed relief and motivation to pursue fights with top opponents like Floyd Mayweather and Manny Pacquiao.

Ferrari team principal Maurizio Arrivabene has revealed that he uses a carrot-and-stick approach to keep Kimi Raikkonen motivated, urging him to stay with the team despite rumors of a potential replacement from Lewis Hamilton. Raikkonen finished on the podium for the first time in 26 races, beating Lewis Hamilton to win the Bahrain Grand Prix. Arrivabene believes Raikkonen's performance demonstrates his commitment to Ferrari, who are keen to retain him due to his experience and reputation. However, there are concerns about Hamilton's future with Mercedes, who may be tempted by the more aggressive approach offered by Ferrari.

Jamaica tops the list as the country with the highest percentage of female bosses, followed closely by Colombia and Saint Lucia, which have the highest percentage of female managers globally, with nearly 60% of managers being female. These three countries account for over half of the world's total female bosses. In contrast, many developed countries like Britain, the US, and others rank lower, with fewer than 40% of managers being female. Despite this, the US ranks high, with 42.7% of managers being female, making it one of the top 20 countries in the world.

A teenager named Violeta Tupuola joins the #kyliejennerchallenge by placing a shot glass over her mouth and sucking in, causing her lips to become ridiculously large and protruding due to the vacuum of air. This bizarre method, inspired by Kylie Jenner's famous pout, has sparked widespread criticism online, with some calling it "dumb" and "gross". Violeta's reaction to the sudden change in appearance has also raised concerns about the potential health risks associated with the procedure.

Stuart McCall urged Rangers to show an immediate response to their second Championship defeat of the season, despite being down 2-0 at halftime against Queen of the South. McCall remained defiant, saying "we've already spoken about going into the playoffs with good momentum" and expected his players to bounce back strongly in their next match. The Ibrox side crashed to a second consecutive defeat, falling to 2-1 at Palmerston Park. McCall praised striker Derek Lyle for scoring the opening goal, which sparked a comeback effort. Rangers remain third in the table, still holding a game in hand over Hibernian.

A horse named Charly was vandalized by tagging him with "RBS" and an arrow made from silver spray paint while he was patrolling Venice Beach with his minders. The LAPD is investigating the incident as a possible example of "art," despite the cruelty involved. Authorities hope to identify the person responsible through the unique signature "RBS." Witnesses reported that the paint came off relatively easily, but the case remains ongoing.

Queens Park Rangers lost 3-3 to Aston Villa at Villa Park, with Clint Hill scoring a crucial equalizer for the home team. Tony Fernandes, Rangers chairman, expressed his despair after the match, stating that his team twice threw away a lead. Despite this, Fernandes remained proud of the performance, praising the team's fighting spirit. The match ended in a draw, with Matt Phillips opening the scoring for QPR.

Tottenham's Harry Kane topped the EA Sports' Performance Index this week, scoring his 30th goal in the Premier League season for Tottenham. He achieved a Game Index score of 55.1 in his latest outing against Newcastle United. Kane's teammate Christian Erisken scored two goals in the 3-1 win, while Eden Hazard finished third with a score of 38.5. This marks Kane's third consecutive win in the Premier League, following wins against Newcastle and Manchester United.

A protective dad in Australia creates a humorous t-shirt with a message warning "Stay Clear Boys" and prints his muscular physique on it for his young daughter, who looks unimpressed. The image sparks mixed reactions online, with some praising the dad's creativity and others mocking him as a "tool." The dad, a two-time World Pro Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu champion, shares the image on social media, captioning it "Hahahha smart dad."

A New York woman was found hanging from a fire escape in Crown Heights, New York, after being left dangling for over an hour. She was identified as a 30-year-old woman with mental health issues, whose body was later confirmed by authorities. Witnesses reported seeing her walking her dog earlier in the day and believing she was a "Halloween prank", but when they went to check on her, they found her hanging outside her apartment building. Her identity remains unknown until notification of her family.

Celtic's actions in the Scottish Cup semi-final against Inverness Caledonian Thistle have sparked widespread criticism, with the club's decision to write to the Scottish Football Association (SFA) claiming a penalty they weren't awarded appears to be a case of "embarrassment" rather than a legitimate complaint. The incident has highlighted concerns about the state of Scottish football, with many questioning whether the governing body is doing enough to address issues such as financial inequality and poor management. A former player, David Raven, who scored the winning goal for Inverness, expressed disappointment and frustration with Celtic's behavior, stating that the club's actions have "taken the gloss off" the sport. The incident has also raised questions about the treatment of players and fans, particularly in relation to the handling of disciplinary matters.

Real Madrid won their Champions League final against Atletico Madrid in Lisbon one year ago, but have struggled to replicate success against their city rivals since then, failing to win any of their last seven games. This will be the eighth meeting between the two teams since last season's final, with Diego Simeone's men emerging victorious on four occasions. Wednesday night's Champions League quarter-final second leg will be the eighth time they have faced each other in the competition. Real Madrid have drawn or lost five times in their last nine meetings with Atletico, while Atletico has won four.

Ile Louët, a secluded island in Brittany, France, offers a unique opportunity for adventurous travelers to experience a peaceful retreat amidst stunning ocean views. With a price tag of €200 (£145) for up to 10 guests, this 19th-century lighthouse cottage provides breathtaking views of Morlaix Bay. Located 1148 feet above sea level, the island is ideal for those seeking solitude and tranquility. The lighthouse keeper's cottage, also available for rent, features a patio area and BBQ space, offering a glimpse into the past.

A 26-year-old Indian man named Boobesh Palani, who was studying in New Zealand, was rescued from shark-infested waters in Wellington Harbour after being dragged by two teenage girls who helped him survive for several hours before being pulled to safety. The man's identity was identified through a post on social media, and he was taken to hospital, where he sadly passed away. The two girls, Kelly and Payge, were praised for their bravery and selflessness in saving his life, despite knowing they were taking a huge risk by entering the water. Their actions were commended by senior police officials, who described their heroic deeds as "exceptional".

Scientists have developed a new material that can generate hydrogen from water, making it a cleaner alternative to traditional methods of producing hydrogen. This breakthrough uses a newly designed molecular catalyst to split water in an electrolyser, reducing the amount of energy required to produce hydrogen. The catalyst is more efficient than existing materials, minimizing energy losses during the process. This innovation could enable the creation of clean and storable hydrogen fuel, paving the way for a more sustainable transportation system.

Labour leader Ed Miliband made his first campaign appearance on the trail in three days after going to ground over the Easter weekend. His first public appearance since Saturday was in Bristol, where he launched a fresh attack on the Tory record on the NHS. Meanwhile, Prime Minister David Cameron continued his campaign trail, visiting constituencies across the UK, including Poole, Dorset, and Edinburgh. Labour MPs expressed concern over Miliband's decision to appear in a third TV debate a week before polling day.

A 38-year-old woman, Julieane Jablonski, has been charged with providing marijuana to a minor and felony tampering with a witness in connection with a case involving her 19-year-old son, Austin Essig, who jumped out of a third-story window after eating a marijuana-laced brownie. Essig had taken the substance to the Fort Collins police department's Facebook page to describe his experience, which included a "trip" that left him feeling unwell. Jablonski was booked on suspicion of both charges.

Liverpool forward Divock Origi has expressed his excitement to join the club after witnessing the progress of its young players, particularly winger Jordan Ibe, and the development of star player Raheem Sterling. Origi joined Liverpool from Lille in a £10 million deal after impressing at the 2014 World Cup in Brazil. He has been following the team's progress from across the English Channel and believes the club's coaching staff, led by Brendan Rodgers, have played a significant role in shaping the team's youth. Origi hopes to learn from the experiences of other young players like Ibe and Sterling, who have improved significantly since joining the club. With seven goals in Ligue 1 this season, Origi believes he will bring a new level of energy and enthusiasm to the team.

A busy mum colours in a child's book, appealing to adults who seek relaxation and creativity through this traditional activity. Scottish illustrator Johanna Basford's bestselling book "Secret Garden" has sold over 1.4 million copies worldwide, outperforming cookbooks and even colour books. The trend of adult colouring-in has gained momentum, with many embracing the calming and meditative experience of colouring in. Experts attribute the appeal to the desire for a break from screens and a chance to engage in a non-digital activity.

The National Health Service (NHS) spent £13 million on suncream in 2014 and £29 million on indigestion pills, despite critics arguing that these items should be rationed due to the NHS's financial struggles. This comes after a damning analysis found that 404,500 prescriptions for suncream and 4.7 million for indigestion pills were handed out in 2014 alone. The NHS is facing a significant financial shortfall, with a predicted gap of at least £8 billion in its annual budget by 2020/21. Critics argue that GPs are prescribing unnecessary items, such as toothpaste and multi-vitamins, and that the system needs to be reformed to prioritize clinical need.

Pilots like flying Boeing 747s, which are considered their "great love", due to their unique design and characteristics. Mark Vanhoenacker, a senior first officer with British Airways, shares his passion for flying these massive aircraft in his book, which explores the intricacies of air travel and the men behind the scenes. His personal connection to the 747 stems from his early days as a pilot, where he flew on medium-distance European flights, and later moved on to Boeing 747s. Vanhoenacker's book delves into the details of flying these iconic planes, including the quirks and features that make them special.

Manchester City manager Alan Pardew insists that despite being six points clear at the top of the Barclays Premier League table, he believes the title race is not over yet. The Eagles' next match is against Crystal Palace, who have already overtaken Liverpool in the standings. In fact, City's victory last season was achieved by coming from behind to win the title with just one game remaining. This experience has given them confidence, as seen in their 2012 Premier League title win, where Sergio Aguero scored a dramatic injury-time winner against QPR. Pardew has ruled out Manchester City of winning the title outright, stating "it's the great thing about the Premier League, you can't take victories for granted."

Manchester United midfielder Michael Carrick has revealed he wants to pursue a career in motorsport, specifically Formula One, after enjoying a successful season with Louis van Gaal's team. At 34, he plans to retire from football and instead focus on racing. Carrick has also expressed his desire to emulate the longevity of legendary teammate Ryan Giggs, who played into his 40s. Despite struggling to adapt to life in London at 15, Carrick credits his move to the city for helping him grow and develop as a person.

A non-profit organization called Wood Green animal charity has partnered with a cleaning and DIY app to offer a cat fostering service, where customers can lend a cat for the day to help scare away mice infestations. The charity has over 200 cats in need of good homes, and the service aims to provide a humane alternative to traditional methods of pest control. The cats will deter mice by leaving a strong scent, while also helping to keep other vegetation under control. The service is available through the Handy app, which allows customers to choose the cat they want to visit their home and receive photos and background information about the animal.

The Coachella festival featured a range of unusual and flamboyant outfits, despite being a celebration of fashion. Celebrities such as Paris Hilton and Kylie Jenner showcased their questionable style choices, including neon-colored outfits, bright floral headgear, and see-through clothing. Despite the overall sense of chaos and excess, some attendees still managed to stand out with their unique and daring fashion statements.

The Sandringham estate has undergone significant changes after removing 62 pieces of hunting memorabilia from public display, replacing them with "trinkets and bric-a-brac". The removal includes stuffed animals such as lions, tigers, and elephants, as well as ivory and rhino horns, which were once displayed in the trophy room. The decision was made to update the display to reflect the shift towards more modern and environmentally friendly practices. The move was seen as embarrassing for Prince William, who had recently spoken out against the wildlife trade.
