A former Adelaide doctor, Tareq Kamleh, who joined the Islamic State, is still practicing medicine in Australia despite appearing in a propaganda video encouraging foreign medics to join the terrorist cult. He was featured in a recent ISIS recruitment video while wearing western-style surgical scrubs and handling babies in a maternity ward, urging people to join the death cult. The Medical Board of Australia has refused to deregister him due to concerns about his conduct, which includes claims of unprotected sex with a patient and promoting extremist ideology. Despite his public support for ISIS, Kamleh remains registered to practice medicine until September 30.

Two siblings, Piper Kulk, 8, and William Kulk, 9, died in a head-on crash on the NSW Central Coast on Sunday morning after their grandmother, Helen Boddy, 54, aqua-planed and swerved into the path of an oncoming ute. The crash occurred when Piper's brother William, 9, died in hospital on Sunday evening. Tributes have poured in for the siblings, with over $32,000 raised online to help the family through a GoFundMe page. The crash followed a similar incident involving a 2-year-old girl in South Australia, as well as a head-on crash in NSW's Hawkesbury region involving a 29-year-old man and his family.

Italian former policeman Dino Maglio has been found guilty of raping a 16-year-old Australian girl after luring her to his home via a couch-surfing website. He claimed the sex was consensual, despite admitting he was "stupid" to spike her drink and drugging her with a tranquilizer. The girl, who was under-age at the time, reported feeling woozy and intensely tired after being served a drink containing the sedative. Maglio's claims of consent were disputed by prosecutors, who alleged he used the tranquilliser to render the girl helpless and vulnerable.

Politicians such as Ed Miliband and Deputy Prime Minister Nick Clegg advise against sexting due to its risks, particularly for younger politicians who may be more vulnerable to exploitation or embarrassment. A quiz featuring questions about the worst thing about politics sparked reactions from both Miliband and Clegg, with Miliband describing it as "a bad advert for all of us" and Clegg calling it "risky". Other politicians, including Green Party leader Natalie Bennett and Education Secretary Nicky Morgan, expressed similar sentiments, stating that sexting is not recommended for anyone, especially for those under 18.

A 48-year-old man, Ian Walters, is accused of murdering his 48-year-old wife, Tracy, after their relationship had collapsed due to her inability to satisfy his sexual demands. Walters, a church treasurer, allegedly smashed his 4x4 vehicle into a tree while driving back from an unsuccessful "make or break" trip with his wife, resulting in her fatal injuries. Walters claims his love life with Tracy was "very fulfilling", describing their sex life as "dramatic". However, he admits to having a troubled relationship with his wife, who had previously reported her husband as being abusive to her.

Manchester Airport was forced to temporarily suspend flights due to a potential drone sighting in airspace near the airport, causing disruptions to hundreds of travelers. Some departing flights were delayed and some incoming flights were diverted to other airports while a police helicopter searched the area. Flights resumed after the police investigation failed to find any evidence of a drone operating in air space used by commercial airliners. Manchester Airport's second runway was opened to clear the backlog of flights, allowing normal traffic to resume.

China's cybercensors have developed a powerful new attack capability called the "Great Cannon", which allows them to launch devastating Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks on servers outside their borders, including in the US. The Great Cannon uses unsuspecting users' internet traffic to disrupt websites like GitHub and GreatFire.org, which provide access to Western news and content that censors dislike. The attack is likely intended to draw international ire and demonstrate Beijing's willingness to take risks to suppress dissent. Researchers believe the Great Cannon is a significant improvement over the Great Firewall, which has long blocked Western news sources, and suggests that China is seeking to expand its influence in the global digital sphere.

Spain's Ciudad Real airport, once a thriving hub serving Madrid and the Andalusian coast, has been left redundant after being sold for £1 per pound. The airport, which was originally valued at €1 billion, was expected to take the overflow from Madrid's Barajas airport, but ultimately failed to attract buyers due to financial difficulties. Despite being designed to showcase modern Spain's affluence, the airport remains empty, with a 4,000-meter runway and 28,000 square feet terminal standing vacant since its closure in 2012.

Detective Patrick Cherry, a member of the NYPD's Joint Terrorism Task Force, appeared on NBC 4 New York to apologize for his outburst against an Uber driver, which was recorded and viewed over 3 million times on YouTube. The incident occurred when the driver honked at Cherry, prompting him to shout and scream, calling the driver "d***" and accusing him of being rude. Cherry was subsequently stripped of his badge and gun and placed on administrative duty, and will be transferred out of the task force. The incident sparked widespread outrage, with many expressing shock and disappointment at Cherry's behavior.

Edwin van der Sar, a former Manchester United goalkeeper, is convinced that Louis van Gaal will bring the glory days back to Old Trafford. The Red Devils head to Chelsea on Saturday in top form after winning six successive matches, putting them within five points of the leaders. With a little bit of luck, United could have challenged for the championship this season, according to van der Sar. However, the current situation suggests that the title is probably beyond their grasp. Despite this, van Gaal has started planning to add new signings to the team in the summer, which may help to revive the club's fortunes.

Bournemouth were out of it until a late Kieran Lee sucker punch from Yann Kermorgant levelled the score, followed by a man sent off for Simon Francis. The Cherries' lead was short-lived, however, as Bournemouth equalised through Callum Wilson's penalty. In stoppage time, Matt Ritchie sealed the win for Sheffield Wednesday with a late strike. Bournemouth ultimately drew the match 2-2.

A 32-year-old man, Carl Garry Chapman, has been charged with multiple offenses related to an abduction of his 18-year-old girlfriend, Billy-Anne Huxham, whom he had previously kidnapped at knife-point. Chapman was found at a friend's home after making contact with a family member, and was subsequently detained and charged with various crimes, including unlawful use of a motor vehicle, entering a dwelling with intent, and assault. Huxham was found at 9.45pm at Aerodrome Road in Maroochydore, after being held captive for several days. She was released when her ex-partner escaped and contacted authorities, and was later charged with similar offenses.

Southampton manager Ronald Koeman wants his team to focus on themselves and start scoring goals after their recent slump in recent weeks. His message to his players is "Forget about the others, focus on yourselves and start scoring goals." With striker Graziano Pelle struggling to find form, Koeman believes he can help turn things around by recalling Senegalese winger Sadio Mane to the starting lineup. The Saints have seven matches left to catch up in the Premier League standings, and Koeman is determined to lead them into the Europa League.

A large population of goldfish has invaded Teller Lake in Boulder, Colorado, after being dumped by someone two or three years ago. The invasive species poses a threat to the local aquatic ecosystem, including native fish such as channel catfish, blue gill fish, and sun fish. Wildlife officials warn that dumping pets into the lake can cause diseases and disrupt the balance of the ecosystem. To address the problem, Colorado Parks and Wildlife is considering either draining the lake or using electrofishing to remove the fish.

Everton's disappointing performance in the Europa League has led to speculation that they may deliver their worst season in nine years. The team's struggles in the competition have been attributed to the demands of playing 10 games in the tournament, rather than any external factors. Roberto Martinez's side fell below expectations, finishing 25 points behind the top two teams in the Premier League. A four-game unbeaten run has also contributed to the team's woes, but Tim Howard insists that the Europa League is not to blame. Despite this, Howard believes that the team can still achieve its goal of finishing in the top half of the Premier League.

The Atlanta Hawks defeated the Brooklyn Nets 131-99 on Saturday night, thanks in part to 20 points each from Al Horford and DeMarre Carroll. However, the Hawks suffered an injury setback when forward Paul Millsap was forced out with a right shoulder injury in the first half. Despite this, the Hawks still managed to secure their 57th win of the season, with Al Horford scoring 20 points and DeMarre Carroll adding 20 points. The Hawks ultimately fell short of matching a franchise record with their 57th win, losing to the Brooklyn Nets 131-99.

New 4G mobile phone services in the UK are not as fast as promised, with an average speed of 2.5 times faster than 3G, according to a recent study by Ofcom. The study found that 4G speeds in the UK are slower than expected, with EE's 4G network delivering the fastest average download speed of 18.6Mbit/s, followed closely by Vodafone's 16.4Mbit/s. The study also showed that upload speeds are improving, but may be slowing due to increased usage. The results contradict the claims made by mobile phone companies that 4G would be five times faster than 3G.

Jimmy Anderson was given a silver cap by Mike Atherton to mark his 100th Test match. The list of fast bowling centurions includes Jimmy Anderson, who reaches this milestone alongside other notable figures such as Courtney Walsh, Glenn McGrath, Chaminda Vaas, Shaun Pollock, and Wasim Akram. Jimmy Anderson was presented with a special cap after reaching 100 Test matches for England. 

Chris Gayle chose to play in the Indian Premier League (IPL) instead of representing West Indies, hitting 21 runs in a loss for Royal Challengers Bangalore. This decision has raised concerns about the priorities of top cricketers, particularly those like Gayle who can earn significant amounts of money through T20 competitions.

Ellia Beasley, a 22-year-old model, had a tattoo of the lyrics "scream your heart out" from the song "Rooftops" by Lost Prophet on her belly when she was a teenager. She regretted the decision after singer Ian Watkins, who was convicted of child sex offenses, was released from prison in 2013. To cover the tattoo, Ellia met with tattoo artist Kevin Paul, who designed a new owl-inspired tattoo on her stomach. The design successfully hid the original lyrics, and Ellia has since had over 20 tattoos, including a giant picture of Ganesh on her back.

Taxi driver Uncle Teng from Shenyang, China, has taken 30,000 selfies with passengers since entering the record books. Known for his infectious smile, which he attributes to coming from within, he captures thousands of photos of his passengers and shares them online. His unique approach involves asking passengers to take a photo with him instead of giving a tip, and he has become a beloved figure in the city, known for spreading joy and positivity through his smiling face.

Mindy Kaling has denied knowing anything about her brother Vijay Chokal-Ingam's decision to pretend to be an African American to get into medical school. Chokal-Ingam, 38, admitted his sister has told him she is "ashamed" of him for opening up about his alleged experience ahead of the release of his new book, Almost Black. Chokal-Ingam claimed he transformed his appearance to gain admission to medical school in 1998, despite his sister saying she was unaware of his decision. The controversy surrounding Chokal-Ingam's claims has sparked a backlash against him, with many accusing him of bringing shame to his family and ignoring systemic racism.

A 53-year-old woman named Julie McKenzie initially thought her back pain was due to scoliosis, a mild curvature of the spine, but was reassured by her GP that it was likely caused by Pilates exercises. However, further investigation revealed that her spine was actually slightly curved, and a tumour was discovered in her coccyx, a benign tumour that is relatively rare. This led to a second opinion from a specialist, who confirmed that the tumour was malignant and required removal. Despite undergoing surgery, Julie continues to experience chronic pain, but is grateful for the diagnosis and treatment, which has improved her quality of life.

A French Bulldog in California became enraged when left alone in a car, continuously honking its horn due to frustration. Ryan Burns captured footage of the incident on his camera phone, which showed the dog standing with its front paws firmly on the horn. The dog's owner disputes the claim, stating the dog was well-cared for and had access to food and water. The incident sparked outrage, with over a million views on YouTube, but also raised questions about animal welfare.

Photographer Anthony Barbour from Liverpool turns typical British locations into individual planets with mind-bending 360-degree photographs by spending hours capturing 50 pictures at each location. His process involves finding the perfect spot, spinning around until he captures all aspects of the scene, and then stitching the photos together in PhotoShop. With a diagnosis of Ulcerative Pan Colitis, Barbour finds photography as an unlikely escape from his illness.

A 21-year-old son of Labour councillor Shakil Ahmed, Waheed Ahmed, was arrested at Birmingham Airport while trying to sneak into Syria with eight of his relatives. He was held at Manchester Airport and later released without charge due to lack of evidence. His father, councillor Shakil Ahmed, refused to comment on his son's arrest, stating that his son is a "good Muslim" and not in danger of being radicalized.

A 32-year-old Massachusetts man, Carlos Colina, has been charged with murder after finding human remains in a duffel bag in Cambridge. He was previously arraigned on charges of assault and battery causing serious bodily injury and improper disposal of a body. Authorities had received a tip about a suspicious item being found in a walkway, which led to his arrest. Colina also faces additional charges related to an unrelated incident involving a 26-year-old victim named Jonathan Camilien, who was found dead in a separate location.

Huddersfield secured a 38-14 Super League victory over Catalans Dragons with a seven-try romp, thanks in part to in-form winger Aaron Murphy's impressive display. Murphy, who has now scored six tries in his last five appearances, scored twice in the match, including one on 15 minutes from Jake Connor's pass. The Huddersfield side dominated the game, scoring six tries in total, including two on 27 minutes when Connor nearly put Murphy in again. The win ends a three-match losing run for Huddersfield, with former Wakefield Wildcats star Murphy playing a key role in securing the victory.

A gang of at least three people poured gasoline on a white Dodge Charger at a California gas station, setting it on fire while the driver was pumping gas. The suspects then attempted to carjack the driver, but were thwarted by him escaping and fleeing the scene. The incident occurred at a 76 Station in South Los Angeles around 12:15am on Saturday. The driver suffered minor injuries but the car was severely damaged, with its entire front end burned beyond repair. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as an arson, and the suspects remain at large.

Hillary Clinton's Twitter follower count appears to be significantly inflated, with estimates suggesting that up to 44% of her followers are fake, making her boast about having 3.6 million followers appear less believable. This is compared to other public figures like President Barack Obama, whose Twitter followers are estimated to be around 2 million, and even some politicians like Vice President Joe Biden, who have fewer than 200,000 followers. Additionally, many of Clinton's supporters on Facebook seem to be fake, with over 46,000 listing Baghdad as their hometown, and a significant portion of her Twitter followers being inactive.

Andrea Dossena, a 33-year-old former Liverpool player, has been arrested on suspicion of shoplifting in Harrods. He was arrested alongside a 31-year-old woman on April 7, after allegedly stealing items valued at £40,000-a-week. Dossena had previously played for Liverpool, scoring the winning goal in their Champions League match against Real Madrid. He signed with League One team Leyton Orient in November, but struggled in the third tier.

A rescue team freed nearly 100 dogs from a blacked-out barn in Tennessee, where they had been living in extreme conditions, including complete darkness, filth, and neglect. The dogs, mostly adults and various breeds, were found to be severely malnourished and suffered from acid burns and maggots infestation. The property owner, Caroline Irby, was charged with 10 counts of animal cruelty and booked into jail. The rescue operation, led by Animal Rescue Corps, aimed to provide medical care and rehabilitation for the dogs, which included treating wounds, administering vaccinations, and providing decompression time.

Michael Easy, a 29-year-old from Southampton, Hampshire, was jailed for a second time for breaching a restraining order and assaulting two prison officers. He posed on Facebook in a silver wig and Dame Edna Everage-style sunglasses, taunting police by posting photographs of himself in a platinum wig and pink glasses. Easy was previously jailed for 15 months in 2013 for assaulting a woman at a party and was released early. He went on the run again in December 2023 and was arrested and sentenced to 4 months in jail for breaching a restraining order and assaulting prison officers.

A 18-year-old Long Islander named Harold Ekeh has been accepted into every Ivy League college, including Yale, after receiving letters from eight institutions. He moved to the US 10 years ago with his parents and has excelled academically, serving as editor-in-chief of his student newspaper and chief executive of the Model United Nations. Despite his impressive academic record, Harold downplays the significance of his achievement, saying "it's just hard work" and that he wants to attend a school where he feels comfortable and can pursue his passions.

The BBC's iPlayer service has experienced issues with uploading the last minutes of various radio shows, leaving frustrated listeners who miss critical parts of programs. The problem, which dates back to 2012, causes shows like "Dad's Army" and "Hancock's Half Hour" to be cut off abruptly. This is due to the live sections of radio stations causing the start and end times of programs to shift, disrupting the automatic recording system. Despite being reported to the BBC in 2012, the issue persists, prompting listeners to seek alternative solutions, such as approaching the Radio 4 program dealing with audience complaints.

The CNN Student News program airs this Friday, featuring topics such as hydraulic fracturing, space exploration, and insect manipulation. To request to be on the show, viewers can submit their school information through the provided link.

Liverpool striker Daniel Sturridge faces a fight to be fit for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa after being left out of Monday night's Barclays Premier League clash due to an injury picked up while playing for Blackburn Rovers. He was also absent from the team for the match against Newcastle United last week. Manager Brendan Rodgers has confirmed that Sturridge will have his fitness monitored ahead of the Wembley showdown on Sunday. With Liverpool already missing Mamadou Sakho, Adam Lallana, and Mario Balotelli through injury and illness, they retain hopes of making the top four in the Premier League.

A teenage burglar, Thomas Buckett, fell 15ft through a roof of a school's tuck shop after being encouraged to do so by friends, resulting in serious head injuries. He was initially sued by the school for £150,000 over the incident, but failed to pursue the claim due to financial constraints. Thomas underwent invasive surgery and suffered life-changing brain injuries, including a 10 skull fracture, and was placed on a lifelong disability pension. The court ruled that the school had not done enough to secure the premises, leading to the family's hefty legal bill.

Jose Mourinho, the Chelsea manager, believes he is improving in every aspect of his job despite facing criticism for his honesty with the media. Despite winning league titles in four countries, Mourinho acknowledges that his tendency to speak truthfully about the team's performance can sometimes land him in trouble. His frankness has led to fines from the Football Association, including a £25,000 penalty for making claims about a perceived campaign against his side. Mourinho attributes his improvement to his growing expertise in various aspects of management, but also notes that he struggles to remain impartial when addressing the media.

Two black candidates were elected to the Ferguson City Council, tripling African-American representation in the St. Louis suburb. The election marks a significant shift in demographics, with half of the six-member council now being African-American. The election comes after a Justice Department report detailed a culture of racism and abuse in the city, sparking protests and calls for reform. The election saw a substantial increase in voter turnout, with 29.4% of registered voters casting their ballots.

Chelsea will face Paris Saint-Germain in a pre-season friendly in North Carolina on July 25, after knocking out Jose Mourinho's side in the Champions League. The Blues will gear up to defend a probable Premier League title with a series of international friendlies, including a match against PSG in July. Chelsea captain John Terry will lead the celebrations as they close in on the title with a 0-0 draw at Arsenal. The team will also face the New York Red Bulls and Barcelona in the US, while Eden Hazard will start for Chelsea in their upcoming matches.

Burnley manager Sean Dyche has called on his teammates to share the goalscoring burden to keep the team in the Premier League, despite striker Danny Ings' struggles for form, which includes a run of eight matches without a goal since February 11. Ings has been linked with a move to Manchester United or Liverpool, and Burnley manager Dyche wants to protect him from being solely responsible for keeping the team in the Premier League. With Ings having scored only one goal in his last seven matches, Dyche believes the rest of the team can help alleviate the pressure on him. Everton manager Roberto Martinez also emphasizes the importance of teamwork and doesn't rule out signing Ings permanently, even though he has expressed doubts about the player's future.

John Chapple is a British photographer known for capturing diverse landscapes, including grassy fields in England, major US cities, and sandy beaches in Australia. NBC's "Nightly News" has officially overtaken ABC's "World News Tonight" in the ratings war for the first time in more than five and a half years, according to Nielsen ratings. Anchor Brian Williams' six-month suspension for misleading viewers about his coverage of the Iraq War in 2003 contributed to the shift. David Muir's "World News Tonight" drew 84,000 more viewers, while NBC's "Nightly News" averaged 9.2 million total viewers. Lester Holt continues to lead NBC's "Nightly News," but the ratings victory marks a significant drop for the network.

Robert Downey Jr, the actor promoting his new film Avengers: Age of Ultron, has been accused of making a racist remark about Oscar-winning Mexican director Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu, who claimed that superhero movies are "cultural genocide". Downey Jr responded by saying that for someone with Spanish as their native language, it would take a person like Inarritu to express such a complex idea. A prisoner who rode in a police van with Freddie Gray claimed that the 25-year-old was trying to injure himself inside the van before he died from unexplained spinal cord injuries. An investigation into Gray's death revealed that he was handcuffed and taken into custody, but the exact circumstances surrounding his injuries remain unclear. The report was released on the same day that a family member of one of the officers defended them on CNN, citing concerns about the department's handling of the case.

Sir Paul McCartney married Heather Mills in 1982, but it wasn't until 2002 that he tied the knot with her. Ferrari driver Sebastian Vettel has returned to the team's factory after a 20-race drought, winning the Malaysian Grand Prix to revive a long-standing ritual. Iona Costello, 51, and her daughter Emily, 51, were found safe and well in New York City's Upper West Side neighborhood after being missing since March 30. A Nigerian Christian prayed for his life while on a rubber dinghy carrying 100 African refugees across the Mediterranean, leading to the deaths of 12 fellow migrants. An investigation found that the migrants were subjected to cruel treatment, including exposure to extreme temperatures and saltwater, leading to multiple deaths. A four-month-old baby named Evan Summerfield died from meningitis just hours after laughing for the first time, leaving his family devastated. A 24-year-old Chicago Cubs fan named Krista Dotzenrod from Minnesota managed to catch a foul ball in her cup of beer during a game against the San Diego Padres on Saturday afternoon. A Czech woman named Dominika Petrinova got revenge on her boyfriend Erik Meldik after he pretended to put their dog Sam in the washing machine, posting a video online that showed him stuck in a chair with wax strips glued to his genitals. Nedum Onuoha is wanted by Hull City, while his former QPR teammate Chris Ramsey is considering streamlining his squad. The Oshun Café, a new single-item menu eatery, has opened in London, serving £6 bowls of Brazilian superfood acai berries. The St Ivan Rilski Church, located in Bulgaria, is the only remaining evidence of the community of Zapalnya, a village that existed from the 13th century until it was forcibly relocated to make way for a dam in the 1960s. Scott Turner Schofield will make his television acting debut on The Bold and the Beautiful, becoming the first transgender man to appear on a daytime soap opera. Rugby injuries are a significant concern, with up to 1 in 8 children suffering injuries serious enough to require at least seven training sessions or matches. Many of these injuries are caused by tackling and scrums, which are considered high-risk activities. To address this issue, the UK government's plans to increase funding and participation in rugby at school are being questioned by experts, who argue that adequate injury surveillance and prevention programs are necessary to mitigate the risks. Tiger Woods, a 14-time major winner, faces significant challenges in his career, but none as daunting as being dwarfed by 7ft 6in former NBA star Yao Ming. Andy Murray defeated 21-year-old Austrian Dominic Thiem in the Miami Open semi-finals, reaching the quarterfinals despite being pushed to 4-4 in the second set. Vincent Kompany joined Manchester City at the age of 17, but his mother insisted he finish his education before joining the club. The Duchess of Cambridge, Kate, has been criticized by leading author Margaret Atwood for being an "uneventful" dresser, dismissing her as a "cavalier" who follows the advice of others rather than taking risks in her fashion choices. A pregnant woman was saved after her partner dived under a capsized boat to retrieve an emergency flare while they were stranded off the coast of Kent in the English Channel. A 17-year-old teenager who had been living at Connecticut Children's Medical Center since December due to chemotherapy for Hodgkin's lymphoma has completed treatment and left the hospital. After completing treatment, Cassandra was released back into the care of the Connecticut Department of Children and Families, which credits the medical team for saving her life. A 10-year-old boy whose body was found in the Mississippi River over the weekend was arrested and charged with second-degree murder. A suicide bomber detonated explosives near a group of protesters in eastern Afghanistan, killing 17 people and wounding 64 others, including an Afghan lawmaker who was injured while participating in the protest. Oscar Hübinette shredded through the snow on the 12,000-foot-tall Tolbachik volcano on the Kamchatka Peninsula in Russia while his friend Fredrik Schenholm photographed his exploits. Newcastle manager John Carver plans to use a whip to motivate his players ahead of the Tyne-Wear derby at the Stadium of Light, saying "in the last four games Sunderland have out-worked us" and that he will "whip" his players to ensure they're motivated to beat Sunderland. Amal Clooney, a high-powered human rights lawyer, called for the release of imprisoned former Maldivian President Mohamed Nasheed during a press conference in Washington DC. 41-year-old mother-of-two has spoken about her journey to becoming a mother and balancing her career and family life. Arsenal midfielder Aaron Ramsey scored a dramatic extra-time winner in the 2014 FA Cup final against Burnley, dedicating the goal to his late grandmother, Gran, whose passing had been a significant influence on his career. Italy has seen a significant increase in migrant arrivals from North Africa, with over 10,000 people arriving since last weekend alone, according to the Italian Coast Guard. The majority of these migrants originated from Libya, where they have been coming for decades due to the lack of control from the port of Tripoli. However, Flay's business partner Laurence Kretchmer dismissed these claims, stating that if Flay had been having an affair, he would have already known about it. The UN's World Meteorological Organization (WMO) has removed the name "Isis" from its list of future Pacific hurricane names due to its association with the militant group. The WMO Hurricane Committee deemed the name inappropriate after considering its connection to the ancient Egyptian goddess. In 2016, "Isis" was on the WMO list of names for hurricanes, but was later removed. The WMO now uses rotating lists of storm names that alternate between male and female, and will use "Ivette" instead of "Isis". The decision follows the removal of "Odile", which was retired due to its association with the terrorist organization the Islamic State.

A large number of Game of Thrones fans have leaked the first four episodes of the show's fifth season online, despite HBO's efforts to prevent it. The leaked episodes, which include characters like Emilia Clarke's Daenerys Targaryen and Nathalie Emmanuel's Missandei, originated from a group authorized to receive them. This is the second-most pirated show after Walking Dead, which has been downloaded over 5.7 million times since 2015. The leak comes just days before the show's debut on HBO Now, which will allow viewers to stream the episodes internationally.

Nicola Sturgeon's Scottish National Party (SNP) has been rejected by voters, with 59% wanting the party to play no part in the next UK government, according to a new ComRes poll. The party's demands, outlined in its manifesto, include extra spending, ending benefits cuts, and scrapping Trident. The SNP also got the biggest thumbs down, with 19% in favor, while Labour is seen as the preferred choice for 59%.

The Moschino collection featured bright pink leathers and super-girly dresses, inspired by the iconic Barbie doll. The collection included dresses with a "spray-on" design, similar to those worn by humans, and a "high-heeled" aesthetic reminiscent of the classic doll. The designs were meant to evoke the nostalgic feeling of playing with toys, but in a grown-up context. Moschino's latest collection seemed to achieve what Jeremy Scott described as "unadulterated whimsy." The collection was met with widespread acclaim, with many praising its unique and playful take on fashion.

Chelsea are planning a victory parade through the streets around Stamford Bridge to celebrate winning the Premier League title in May, if they achieve it. The parade will take place on May 25, starting around 12pm and ending at 1pm. The planned route includes stops at Eel Brook Common and Parsons Green. A letter from Hammersmith and Fulham council has been sent to residents outlining the plan, which also mentions a potential Chelsea football club parade in the area. If Chelsea win the title, a victory parade will take place on May 25.

Jack Henry Doshay, 22, a son of influential San Diego businessman Glenn Doshay, was arrested for allegedly attempting to kidnap a 7-year-old girl from a local elementary school. Doshay appeared in court for the first time on Friday, pleading not guilty to charges of kidnapping, false imprisonment with violence, and child cruelty. The girl was not identified, but her father, Mike Paeske, described her as "our inspiration" and "hero". Doshay was arrested nine days after the alleged incident, which occurred on March 23, while he was seeking treatment for depression at a residential facility.

Sri Lanka's Kumar Sangakkara should reconsider his decision to retire from limited overs cricket and continue for another year, according to Sri Lanka's sports minister. Sangakkara bid farewell to the one-day game on March 18, disappointed with a World Cup quarter-final defeat. Sangakkara scored four successive centuries before bowing out of the Cricket World Cup. As the sports minister, Navin Dissanayake humbly requested Sangakkara to serve the country for another year. Sangakkara played a key role in Sri Lanka's success, scoring 541 runs in the tournament, including four successive centuries.

Nicola Sturgeon, the leader of the Scottish National Party (SNP), has called for the retirement age to be frozen in response to the rising death rate among Scottish pensioners. This move would cost billions of pounds, despite the fact that Scottish pensioners tend to live shorter lives compared to those in other parts of the UK. The SNP demands that the retirement age be frozen due to concerns over the impact on pensioners' financial security. They argue that this decision would disproportionately affect those living in Scotland, where life expectancy is already lower than in other regions.

A series of mysterious cardboard signs have appeared in a Surrey village, sparking speculation about the identity of the author and the reason behind the contrite gesture. The signs, written in black marker pen, feature messages such as "please forgive me" and "we need to talk", and include phrases like "I love you" and "do much please forgive". Five Chinese feminist activists, including Li Tingting, Wei Tingting, Wang Man, Zheng Churan, and Wu Rongrong, have been detained by police for more than a month for "picking quarrels and provoking trouble" after being arrested while handing out leaflets about sexual harassment on public transport on International Women's Day. The family of the activists has issued a plea for their release, citing prolonged detention and lack of explanation. The Chinese government has charged the women with "picking quarrels and provoking trouble", a vague charge often used to justify detentions of dissidents. The activists' detention has sparked international condemnation, with the US, UK, and EU expressing concerns about human rights abuses.

A vast sea of pilgrims from both Australia and New Zealand have gathered at the Anzac Commemorative Site to mark the 100th anniversary of the bloody Gallipoli landings. The ceremony honors the thousands of Australians and New Zealanders who fought in the World War I Gallipoli campaign, which began on April 25, 1915. The event includes a dawn service at the Gallipoli dawn service, where Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott praised the troops as "founding heroes of modern Australia". Over 10,000 people have gathered to pay their respects, including Prince Charles, Prince Harry, and New Zealand Prime Minister John Key.

Fernando Torres scored his first-ever league goal as Atletico Madrid drew 2-2 with Malaga, pulling the visitors back into the game with an own goal in the 45th minute. The Spanish striker had previously struggled to find form since returning to the team in January, scoring only four goals. Malaga goalkeeper Carlos Kameni made a crucial save to prevent a clean sheet, but ultimately couldn't stem the tide of Atletico's comeback. The match ended in a 2-2 draw, keeping Atletico in third place in La Liga.

Danny Lennon has been appointed as the new manager of Scotland Under 21 football team, replacing interim coach Paddy Connolly. He will lead the team until the summer of 2016. Lennon previously managed Scotland U21 from 2014 to 2015 before taking over as interim coach. His tenure saw a 2-1 victory against Hungary in their most recent friendly match. Lennon will leave his position as interim coach after agreeing a deal to become the permanent manager of Scottish Championship club Alloa Athletic.

A battered and worn-out bus and train were used to film a pivotal scene in the 1993 movie "The Fugitive", where Harrison Ford's character Dr Richard Kimble escapes from a prison transport by jumping from the bus into the path of an onrushing train. The scene was filmed in the Great Smokey Mountains in North Carolina, lying abandoned for 23 years until it was rediscovered. Director Andrew Davis used 13 cameras to capture the intense 60-second sequence, which was shot for a mere $1.5 million. The wreckage of the bus and train remain on location, serving as a popular tourist attraction today.

A 28-year-old man, believed to be 20-year-old Bradley James Brooks, was charged with murder after stabbing a 28-year-old man, Greg Gibbins, outside a pizza shop in the early hours of Easter Monday. Gibbins, a talented football player, was attacked while helping a woman being harassed earlier in the night. He died in hospital after being stabbed in the chest. Brooks was arrested and charged with murder, and is currently being held without bail. The investigation is ongoing, and police are reviewing CCTV footage from the hotel to determine if the attack was linked to a previous incident involving a woman.

A new Reddit thread is exploring the lives of men who have purchased mail-order brides from Russia and the Philippines, revealing surprising reactions to starting relationships with their spouses. The discussion, which has garnered over 10,000 comments, asks users to share what shocked them the most about their experiences. Many men reported feeling awkwardness and lack of emotional connection with their wives, despite initial excitement and attraction. However, some men discovered that their wives were motivated by financial gain rather than love, leading to disappointment and heartbreak.

Manchester City goalkeeper Joe Hart expressed disappointment and frustration after a 4-2 defeat to Manchester United, acknowledging that his team's bid to retain the Premier League title was over. He described the game as "one of his worst in a Manchester City shirt" and stated that the team's performance was "morale-sapping". Hart was unable to prevent goals from Ashley Young, Marouane Fellaini, Juan Mata, and Chris Smalling, and admitted that the team had let their fans down. With Manchester City now four points behind rivals United and 12 behind runaway leaders Chelsea, Hart reflected on the team's struggles in recent weeks, which have seen them take just 18 points from a possible 39.

A Northern Territory mother, Noeleen Foster, spotted a phallic-shaped cloud while working at a construction site in Zuccoli, 25km southeast of Darwin. She was thrilled to capture the unusual formation with her phone camera. This isn't the first time a phallic cloud has been photographed, as a similar shape was seen in Debyshire, England last year. Loren Mathieson filmed her pet Boston Terrier, Gizmo, performing a gravity-defying stunt at home after trying on new black booties. The footage shows Gizmo taking a few steps forward before planting down his front feet and launching into a vertical jump. Porto, the only undefeated side in the Champions League, face off against Bayern Munich in their quarter-final first leg at home. Julen Lopetegui, the team's manager, believes Porto can enjoy their achievement of being unbeaten despite coming up against one of the most successful teams in the competition. The match marks a clash between two of the tournament's most prolific scorers, with Porto boasting a strong defensive record and Bayern Munich having conceded fewest chances against them. Lopetegui and Bayern Munich's Pep Guardiola have shown respect for each other's achievements, with Guardiola praising Porto's recent performances. Porto's defense has been particularly impressive, conceding just five goals all season and scoring 24.

A 9-year-old boy named Frankie Franz from Dagenham and Redbridge Football Club attempted to emulate Barcelona star Martin Montoya's impressive 27-yard goal-scoring feat by attempting to kick a basketball hoop into the net. The video showed him successfully doing so, with his mother Lucy commenting that she thinks her son might be ready to try again. Frankie's attempt was caught on camera, and he was left gobsmacked when he sent the ball through the hoop for the second time.

Maksims Uvarenko, a financially-strained Latvian goalkeeper for CSKA Sofia, has not received payment for three months due to unpaid rent and debt issues. Despite facing financial troubles, he has expressed appreciation for the unique passion and support of the fans, describing them as "the biggest problem" he's faced at the club. Parma pulled off the biggest surprise of the season as the crisis-hit club beat runaway leaders Juventus 1-0 in Serie A, inflicting what was only the second defeat of the campaign for Massimiliano Allegri's side. Jose Mauri scored the only goal of the game on the hour mark, while a string of fine saves from Parma goalkeeper Antonio Mirante also helped Roberto Donadoni's side to a memorable win. Parma were declared bankrupt last month and the players have not been paid all season, but they has now strung a series of positive results together, with a 1-0 victory over Udinese midweek and last weekend's 1-1 draw at Inter Milan.

Photographer Simon Brann Thorpe began his project "Toy Soldiers" by driving himself into the desert of Western Sahara, where he used the harsh landscape as a backdrop for soldiers posing as green plastic figurines, similar to popular toys. The project aims to create a visual metaphor that sparks a viewer's emotional, physical, and political response to war and conflict. Despite receiving no mainstream media coverage, the conflict in Western Sahara remains unresolved due to its lack of representation. Thorpe's photographs showcase the reality of life in the region, highlighting the suffering of the people living in refugee camps and occupied territories.

A seven-year-old boy was raped and set on fire by two youths while buying food in Pagma Nagar, Mumbai. The incident involved attempted rape and assault, with the youths taking the boy to an isolated area where he was subjected to physical harm. Despite suffering severe burns, the boy managed to escape. An investigation is underway, with charges under various laws, including attempt to murder and sodomy. The boy is receiving treatment at a nearby hospital.

Jurgen Klopp confirmed that he will leave Borussia Dortmund at the end of the season after seven years in charge, putting England's top clubs on alert. He was installed as the bookmakers' favourite to replace Manuel Pellegrini at Manchester City, but Dortmund bosses have no plans to make such a move. Klopp will officially cease to be Dortmund manager on June 30 and is expected to join a new club soon. The 47-year-old coach believes Dortmund needs a change due to the team's struggles, having lost key players like Mario Gotze and Robert Lewandowski.

Sean McCabe, a father of three, planned his own funeral after being told he had stage four Hodgkin Lymphoma, but after a miraculous recovery, he rebooked the church for his wedding to fiancée Lisa Williams. His cancer went into remission, and he is now due to marry her on July 25.

A 8-year-old boy died after his family's car crashed into the Los Angeles harbor, while their 13-year-old son was pulled from the water shortly after. The family of four, including the father, were rescued by firefighters and taken to the hospital, where both children have died. A firefighter who dove into the water to rescue the children has been hailed a hero. The incident occurred when the family's car veered off the edge of the harbor and plunged into the water.

Qatar's investment arm, Qatar Holding, has acquired a majority stake in the company behind the iconic Claridge's hotel in London, marking its tightening grip on the city's real estate market. This move comes after Constellation Hotels, a Gulf state-owned company, purchased a 64% stake in hotel company Coroin, which owns five-star establishments such as Claridge's, The Berkeley, and The Connaught. The acquisition is part of Qatar's expanding portfolio of high-profile properties, including The Shard, Harrods, and One Canada Tower.

A mother, Akon Guode, 35, was released from custody after being interviewed by police regarding the deaths of her three children, aged one, one, and four, who drowned in a car crash near Melbourne's outer west. The car, a grey 2005 Toyota Kluger, crashed into a lake at Wyndham Vale on Wednesday evening, killing all three children. The mother claimed she is innocent and says the children adored her, while the father of the children defended her, stating she is a "good mother". The incident has sparked widespread grief and outrage among the Sudanese community, with many paying their respects to the victims at a makeshift shrine.

Researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have developed an algorithm that analyzes keystrokes to detect early signs of Parkinson's disease, potentially revealing a huge amount of information about a person's motor skills. A common computer keyboard could be a powerful tool in their battle against the disease, allowing doctors to identify individuals with the condition earlier than currently possible. The six-minute test involves analyzing the timing and duration of keystrokes to determine if a person is experiencing motor difficulties. Preliminary results show that the algorithm can accurately detect Parkinson's disease with a remarkable 85% accuracy, suggesting that it may be a valuable diagnostic tool.

Raheem Sterling has moved a step closer to an Anfield exit after revealing in a TV interview that he is not ready to sign a new contract at Anfield. Sterling, 20, has been offered a new £100,000-a-week deal to stay at the club but admitted he is 'flattered' by interest from Arsenal.

Stoke boss Mark Hughes has dismissed recent reports linking Asmir Begovic with a move away from the Britannia Stadium, saying "there will be a lot of stories bandied about" but he doesn't believe them to be true. The 27-year-old Bosnian goalkeeper has been linked with a transfer to Spanish giants Real Madrid, despite being out of contract in 2016. Stoke keeper Asmir Begovic has been linked with a summer move to Real Madrid, but Hughes says "I don't think that is true". The Potters are also hoping to complete the signing of teenage winger Moha El Ouriachi from Barcelona, who is set to join from the same club where he was previously signed by Stoke.

Gerard T. "The Frenchman" Ouimette, a former mob enforcer from Rhode Island, died in a federal prison in North Carolina on Sunday at the age of 75. Ouimette was suspected of having a role in up to eight murders and ran the federal prison in North Carolina in the 1970s. He controlled a large gangster network involved in various crimes, including extortion, loansharking, and murder. Ouimette was convicted of extortion in 1996 and became the first criminal in New England sentenced to life in prison under the federal "three strikes and you're out" provision.

Danny Cipriani has taken advantage of a rare free weekend from rugby after helping Sale Sharks to a 23-6 victory against Gloucester last Saturday. He contributed 13 points from the boot in a fine display, which helped him relax on holiday in Dubai. With Sale out of contention in Europe, Cipriani has the weekend off to recharge ahead of their final four Aviva Premiership games. The team will face London Irish, Harlequins, Newcastle, and Exeter in the coming weeks as they aim to secure a top-six finish and qualification for the European Champions Cup.

Owen Farrell, the Saracens fly-half, is hopeful of returning to form after missing the entire RBS 6 Nations campaign due to a knee ligament injury sustained against Clermont Auvergne in January. He hopes to be in contention for the European Champions Cup semi-final against the French side on April 18. Farrell has been sidelined since suffering the injury and has been working hard in training to regain fitness. His return to the pitch could come sooner rather than later, with the Saracens set to face Leicester at Allianz Park before taking on Clermont in Saint Etienne seven days later.

Officer Michael Slager, 33, is being held in jail on murder charges after opening fire on Walter Scott, 50, in North Charleston, South Carolina, after allegedly stopping him over a broken tail light. Slager is housed in a room with limited interaction with other inmates due to security concerns. His attorney claims that Slager is not allowed to interact with other prisoners while in custody. Slager is facing charges related to the fatal shooting of Scott, who was stopped by Slager over a broken tail light.

A woman in New York City paid $16,000 for a 35-minute car ride from her East Williamsburg apartment to Midtown East through UberX, but was shocked to discover that the bill was incorrect and she was overcharged by $11,000. Despite initially disputing the charges, Uber claimed it was a clerical error and offered to refund the amount, but the woman still disputed the final bill, which included a $4,000 refund.

A cloud formation resembling the Wi-Fi symbol appeared in central China, creating a "giant Wifi Cloud" in Xiangtan city, Hunan Province, last week. This phenomenon was likened to God's router, with some jokingly suggesting that technology university students may not need WiFi after all. The image was captured by Shi Chao, who posted it on Weibo, where it quickly went viral. The cloud formed in response to a lack of WiFi coverage in the area.

Arsenal midfielder Jack Wilshere met Brazilian legend Pele at the launch party of 10Ten Talent, where he was given the opportunity to interview the three-time World Cup winner. Wilshere was starstruck after meeting Pele, who posed for a photo with him and tweeted "Looking forward to meeting @Pele tonight" alongside other clients Glenn Hoddle and Pele. A growing number of migrants from Africa and the Middle East are attempting to cross the Mediterranean Sea into Italy, with over 8,480 rescued between Friday and Monday. A migrant boat carrying approximately 550 people capsized in the Mediterranean Sea off the Libyan coast, prompting concerns about its safety. Despite efforts by the Italian Coast Guard, no survivors or bodies have been found, leading some to fear that many migrants may be lost. The crisis has resulted in at least 480 deaths since the start of the year due to bad weather and overcrowding, with many migrants relying on aid from rescue operations.

Jacques Burger, a 31-year-old Namibian rugby player, has been cited for alleged foul play during a European Champions Cup quarter-final match against Racing Metro in Paris. He allegedly struck Racing scrum-half Maxime Machenaud midway through the game, leading to a disciplinary hearing. Burger faces a possible two-week ban, with punishments ranging from eight weeks to 52 weeks. The incident occurred on Sunday and was reported by match citing commissioner Eugene Ryan. A separate hearing will be held on Thursday to determine the outcome of the case.

Chile's Calbuco Volcano erupted again on Thursday, marking its third eruption since last week, with a spectacular but not as severe event compared to previous ones. The volcano, located near Lake Llanquihue, produced an extensive plume and was described by photographer Gregorio Billikopf as "spectacular" but not as intense as the previous eruptions. Over 1,500 people were evacuated due to the evacuation of homes and livestock, while security measures continued as contingency plans remained in place. The eruption added to the existing ash cloud, which had already spread to Argentina and affected nearby areas.

Six people have been arrested in Dover on suspicion of Syria-related terrorism offences, with five men and one woman detained at approximately 8am in the departure zone of the south coast port. The arrests are part of an ongoing investigation, which includes searches at several addresses in Birmingham and the West Midlands area. The suspects, who are not a family group, do not pose an immediate threat to public safety. Two individuals, Waheed Ahmed and his aunt, cousins, and four children, were arrested in Hatay province, southern Turkey, where they were stopped by security forces.

Philadelphia beat New York City FC 2-1 for their first Major League Soccer victory of the season on Saturday. Zach Pfeffer started the scoring in the 27th minute for Philadelphia. Sebastien Le Toux beat his defender, dribbling to the goal-line and feeding it to Pfeffer, who scored from close range to round off a classy New York City goal. David Villa scored from close range to round off a classy New York City goal, but couldn't prevent a defeat. New York answered a minute later when Damien Perrinelle headed in Felipe's corner kick for his first MLS goal. San Jose Earthquakes midfielder Sanna Nyassi scored the only goal in his team's win over Vancouver, ending Houston's 274-minute scoring drought.

A 41-year-old Ghanaian-British church preacher, Eric Isaiah Adusah, is being held on suspicion of murdering his pregnant wife, Charmain Adusah, 41, in a hotel room in Ghana. The body of Charmain was discovered by hotel staff face down in a bath, believed to have been lying for four days. The couple had a whirlwind romance before marrying in September, with Eric Adusah allegedly leaving the hotel hurriedly on the day Charmain died.

Ethan Czahor has launched 'Clear', an app that removes any posts on Twitter that may cause problems with employers or future employers. The app uses IBM's Watson supercomputer to analyze tweets and determine whether they contain potentially problematic content. It identifies "troll-like" behavior, such as hate speech, sexism, and homophobia, and provides users with a safety rating based on the severity of the content. The app aims to help individuals protect themselves from online harassment and maintain a professional online presence.

Justin Rose will try to build on his recent success by taking a page from Rory McIlroy's playbook, aiming to replicate his strong start to the season with a second-place finish at the Masters. Rose arrived at Augusta National with renewed enthusiasm and a 14-under-par total, which has only been matched six times in Masters history. He finished second at the tournament, beating out Jordan Spieth, and believes his finish can help boost his season with upcoming big events. Rose also drew inspiration from Rory McIlroy's successful summer of 2014, which included wins at the Open, Bridgestone Invitational, and US PGA. With a renewed sense of purpose, Rose aims to sustain his Augusta form and become the first European player to win the US Open and Masters.

A college student at a Texas-based country music festival, Chilifest, used Rock Paper Scissors to avoid getting caught drinking underage and was able to escape punishment due to beating three police officers playing the game. The incident occurred during the festival, where the student was challenged by an officer to a game of Rock Paper Scissors, and emerged victorious, earning herself a free pass. The video of the event was posted online and quickly gained widespread attention, with many users expressing shock and amusement at the leniency of the police. The incident highlights the unpredictable nature of law enforcement at large events like festivals.

A 14-year-old girl named Sally Gordon-Smith went missing near Melbourne after being last seen leaving her school in Keilor East at 3pm on Friday. Police are desperately searching for her due to her young age. She was described as Caucasian, 150cm tall, with blue eyes and brown shoulder-length hair, and was wearing blue jeans, a black jumper, and black shoes when she disappeared. The police appeal for information comes just hours after she vanished from view.

Crystal Palace manager Alan Pardew insists he is not interested in raiding former club Newcastle for goalkeeper Tim Krul, despite reports emerging suggesting he was planning a move. Pardew took over at Crystal Palace in January and led the team on an impressive run of form, pulling them away from relegation. He has maintained a positive relationship with current goalkeeper Julian Speroni and denies any interest in signing Krul. Pardew claims there's been no contact with Newcastle or Krul regarding a potential transfer.

British photographer John Daniels has captured adorable images of puppies posing for the camera through a series of photo shoots in his studio. Using both clean white backgrounds and comedy props, Daniels has created heartwarming pictures of various animals, including kittens, puppies, ducks, rabbits, and even a duck and a duckling. His approach involves experimenting with unusual pairings and using specific techniques to achieve the desired effect. With years of experience working with animals, Daniels aims to create "picture-perfect" shots that showcase the beauty and charm of his subjects.

A 54-year-old woman, Hilary Border, from Newark, Nottinghamshire, stole £20,000 from her 83-year-old mother, Dorothy, who suffers from dementia, by taking the funds without paying the required care home fees. Border had power of attorney over her mother's finances due to her deteriorating health, but failed to pay the fees despite receiving an outstanding debt of £16,000. Care home staff reported the theft to the police, which led to Border pleading guilty to fraud. She was sentenced to 16 months in prison, suspended for two years, after taking the £20,000 between October 2012 and November 2019.

David Suchet, 68, is a devoted grandfather to his grandson Todd, who has Tuberous Sclerosis Complex, a rare genetic disease that requires treatment. Despite being diagnosed at birth, Suchet's grandson is still battling to receive necessary medical attention due to "mismanagement" in the NHS. Suchet, best known for his role as Hercule Poirot, is fighting for better treatment options for those with rare diseases like his own grandson's condition. He is urging others to use the hashtag #Fight4Treatment to raise awareness and pressure the government to improve healthcare services.

Cheteshwar Pujara has been signed by Yorkshire until the end of May after cancelling the contract of Younis Khan, who was previously set to join the team for 2015. The move comes after Pujara expressed interest in joining Yorkshire, where he will link up with the Division One champions. Pujara, 27, joins from India and will spend time with Derbyshire before potentially making his debut for Yorkshire. He is expected to score a significant number of runs for the county, with over 9,000 first-class runs under his belt.

US Army Staff Sergeant Julian McDonald welcomed 4-year-old Belgian Malinois Layka into his home in Columbus, Ohio, after fighting to adopt her for two years. Layka was injured in Afghanistan but completed the mission with her team and received treatment for her wounds. Despite being injured, she adapted to civilian life quickly and became fast friends with McDonald's son Liam. McDonald decided to bring Layka home to live with his family due to her bravery and loyalty.

New research questions conventional wisdom on salt consumption, suggesting that the average American's daily salt intake may not pose significant health risks despite warnings from medical experts. Current guidelines recommend limiting salt to 2,300 milligrams per day, but some scientists argue that this amount carries no risk. However, studies suggest that excessive salt consumption can lead to cardiovascular problems, while insufficient salt consumption can also cause harm. Experts disagree on the optimal level of salt intake, with some arguing that up to 6,000 milligrams per day is safe for most people. Despite warnings from the American Heart Association, some critics claim that reducing salt consumption can lower blood pressure, while others argue that this is not supported by scientific evidence.

US Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) agents in Colombia were involved in alleged'sex parties' with prostitutes funded by drug cartels from 2001, according to a new report. Several DEA agents participated in these parties, which included those who later admitted to sleeping with prostitutes while on overseas assignments. A previous report found that at least 10 DEA agents admitted to engaging in sex parties on government-leased property, using taxpayer money to pay for prostitutes. The allegations come amid a growing scandal involving other law enforcement agencies, including the Secret Service, which faced criticism for its handling of a prostitution scandal in Cartagena, Colombia.

A 36-year-old Louisiana sheriff's deputy, Burt Hazeltine, was shot three times while directing traffic near a school zone in Paradis, Louisiana, during a road rage incident sparked by a verbal dispute over traffic. Paul Devillier, a 56-year-old Transportation Safety Administration worker, opened fire on Hazeltine, hitting him multiple times, including in the face, elbow, and eye. Hazeltine was rushed to Interim LSU Hospital, where he is currently in stable but guarded condition. Devillier had two guns on him at the time of his arrest.

Lord Janner, a 86-year-old peer, signed a letter stating he wanted to remain a member of the House of Lords despite facing child sex charges due to his dementia. Critics argue that he should not be allowed to remain in the House of Lords, given his frailty. The Crown Prosecution Service announced that Janner would escape prosecution due to his Alzheimer's disease, sparking controversy and accusations of a cover-up.

Turkey has blocked access to Twitter and YouTube after refusing to remove pictures of a prosecutor held during an armed siege last week, citing "deeply upsetting" images of the deadly event. The prosecutor, Mehmet Selim Kiraz, was killed in a standoff with members of the Revolutionary People's Liberation Party-Front (DHKP-C), a far-left organization, while investigating the death of another victim, Berkin Elvan. The Turkish court ordered the blocks due to the widespread sharing of images on social media. The blocks follow a pattern of previous restrictions on social media sites in Turkey, which have been imposed in response to similar incidents.

David and Victoria Beckham have won a planning battle against their neighbor over proposals to install air conditioning at their £31.5 million West London mansion. The couple wants to install air conditioning in five rooms, including a luxury gym and wine cellar. Their neighbor was concerned about the impact on the historic character of the Victorian house, but the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea Council approved the plans subject to minor conditions.

California Governor Jerry Brown ordered a 25% overall cutback in water use by cities and towns in the state due to the ongoing drought, despite the lush and technicolor landscapes of the region. This move aims to reduce water consumption, but critics argue it may not be effective given the state's arid climate. The cutback affects affluent areas with large amounts of landscaping, such as golf courses and residential properties, while exempting agriculture, which accounts for 80% of the state's water usage.

Furious 7, the final film from late actor Paul Walker, is expected to gross $115 million or more upon its domestic opening, making it the top showing ever for an April title, not accounting for inflation. The movie opens on April 27th, 2017, in approximately 4,003 theaters across the US, setting a new record for the country's largest release. It is also poised to do massive business overseas, potentially reaching $250 million globally. The film features a star-studded cast, including Vin Diesel, Michelle Rodriguez, and Tyrese Gibson, and follows the continuation of the street-racing series.

Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas struggles during the second half of the season after a brilliant start to the year, which included a 2-0 defeat to Holland. He was captain of Spain when the team lost 2-0, despite having a strong performance earlier in the season. Fabregas' form has dipped significantly, with only 15 Premier League assists in 15 games since October, compared to 20 in the same period last season. His manager Jose Mourinho is concerned about Fabregas' durability due to the heavy workload, and the midfielder needs to find form quickly to help Chelsea secure the Premier League title. With the season nearing its end, Fabregas faces a tough task to revive his fortunes and lead the Blues to victory.

A group of 750 plaintiffs, including victims and their families, are suing Johns Hopkins University over a horrific medical experiment in Guatemala where the US tested syphilis on unwittingly infected individuals, resulting in severe physical and emotional trauma. The study, which took place from 1945 to 1956, involved deliberately infecting individuals with syphilis, including children, orphans, and others, including soldiers, prostitutes, and mentally ill patients. The victims suffered from various health issues, including blindness, severe disabilities, and brain damage, and some were forced to pass the disease on to their children. The US government initially denied involvement in the study, but was forced to admit it in 2010 after a whistleblower came forward. The plaintiffs are seeking $1 billion in damages, citing the harm caused by the study and the suffering endured by the victims and their families.

Hip-hop star Nelly, 40, has been arrested in Tennessee on drug charges after being pulled over by a state trooper on his private bus while driving through Putnam County. Authorities say he was charged with felony possession of drugs, simple possession of marijuana, and possession of drug paraphernalia. A search of the bus found evidence of methamphetamine, marijuana, and other drug-related items, including handguns and ziplock bags. Nelly was taken into custody and released on bail before posting a $10,000 bond.

A Japanese woman gave her cheating boyfriend's expensive Apple collection a "good wash" by soaking his iMac in a bathtub, causing irreparable damage. The incident sparked a mix of reactions online, with some praising the woman's "best revenge" and others condemning it as harsh. Many agreed that destroying a person's belongings is never an acceptable solution, but the woman's actions seemed to have gone too far. Despite the backlash, she received support from many, including @womenspeakup, who argued that the man should count his lucky stars that it was his own device that suffered damage.

Bayern Munich won 1-0 against Borussia Dortmund in their Bundesliga match, with Robert Lewandowski scoring the winning goal. Jurgen Klopp conceded that Bayern Munich were the better team, while Dortmund coach Jurgen Klopp felt that his side lacked punch and deserved to lose. Dortmund captain Mats Hummels disagreed with Klopp, saying that the 10th-place side merited more chances to win. Despite Lewandowski's impressive performance, Bayern Munich ultimately claimed the three points, moving 10 points clear at the top of the table.

He met with Simpson Miller and other Caribbean prime ministers Thursday before departing for the Summit of the Americas in Panama. He is off for another historic meeting with Cuba's President Raul Castro. 

Summary:

US President Barack Obama visited Jamaica on Thursday, becoming the first American president to do so since President Ronald Reagan in 1982. He met with Jamaican Prime Minister Portia Simpson Miller and expressed his love for the country and its people. Obama also met with Cuban President Raul Castro, who welcomed him warmly, and discussed ways to improve relations between the two nations. The US State Department has recommended removing Cuba from the list of countries that support terrorism, a move that could help ease tensions between the two nations.

Pope Francis reminded the world of the Vatican's status as a state and its role as a moral diplomat, calling for an end to violence and bloodshed in various conflicts worldwide. He specifically addressed issues in Iraq, Syria, Israel-Palestine, Libya, Iran, Yemen, Nigeria, and Kenya, urging humanitarian aid and peace. The Pope expressed hope for peace in Ukraine and healing for those affected by conflict. He also emphasized the importance of addressing economic oppression, asking for peace and freedom from those who exploit others.

Linda Farrow eyewear's Spring Summer 15 campaign features Irina Shayk posing in a swimsuit and shades while filming a steamy scene with model Jarrod Scott in a pool. The video showcases the brand's new round frame gold plated sunglasses, which Irina wears in various outfits. The campaign follows the couple as they cavort around a LA pool, highlighting their glamorous summer look.

A Polish prince named Janek Zylinski has challenged Nigel Farage, the leader of Ukip, to a sword fight over his criticism of immigration. Zylinski, the son of a Polish war hero who fought against the Nazis in 1939, claims he "had enough" of Farage's attacks on immigrants. Zylinski posts a video introducing a gold sculpture of his father and announcing the challenge, saying they must meet in Hyde Park to resolve the issue. Zylinski brands Farage as "idiotic" for blaming migrants for traffic jams, while Farage defends himself, stating that he believes immigrants bring skills to the UK.

Barcelona defender Dani Alves has been offered a two-year deal with an option for a third year, contingent on playing a certain number of matches, according to his camp. This development has raised questions about whether he will ultimately decide to stay at the club or join Manchester United instead. Alves' camp says the offer is a one-year deal to be renewed for a second year, followed by a third year if he meets specific performance targets. However, Alves' agent, Dinorah Santa Ana, has expressed doubts about the likelihood of United making a serious bid for him.

Kate Temple, a 33-year-old hairdresser, was jailed for 20 months after admitting to inflicting grievous bodily harm on victim Shelley Williams, who had her ear bitten off during a dispute at a charity event. The incident occurred at Dawdon Cricket Club in Seaham, County Durham, where Temple and her sister attempted to buy drinks while the victim was refusing service. Temple was subsequently arrested and charged with GBH, but pleaded guilty to the charge and was sentenced to 20 months in prison.

Jenson Button believes McLaren now have their rivals in their sights ahead of this weekend's Chinese Grand Prix, having made significant progress despite starting the season with a lack of pace in Australia. In contrast, McLaren and new power-unit supplier Honda improved upon their performance in Malaysia, discovering the car was competitive alongside midfield runners. Button hopes further steps have been taken to improve, particularly regarding downforce and power unit development. He also notes that the cooler air in Shanghai may hinder progress, but the team is making strides nonetheless. Button returns to the garage after retiring during the Malaysian Grand Prix, where he saw his team discover the car's potential.

Claudia Martins, 33, a mother-of-five, was convicted of suffocating her newborn baby daughter by filling her mouth with toilet paper and hiding the body in a suitcase. The 33-year-old gave birth alone at her sister's flat, keeping the pregnancy a secret from her family and friends. Martins was acquitted of murder but convicted of manslaughter by reason of diminished responsibility due to her extremely low IQ. The baby was discovered dead in the suitcase on September 15, and police investigated the circumstances surrounding the crime.

AP McCoy's mount, Mr Mole, has been installed as one of three 7-2 co-favourites in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. The Grade One race will feature Paul Nicholls' trained Mr Mole, who will be ridden by Nico de Boinville in the absence of injured Barry Geraghty. This will be McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race before he quits riding. Mr Mole will also compete against other notable riders, including Mick Channon's Somersby.
