Jason Holder's impressive performance in the second Test will help shape the culture of the West Indies as new coach Phil Simmons tries to create a winning mentality among his players. Marlon Samuels' achievement of reaching a century in the second Test demonstrates the value of taking Tests seriously, even in a modern era dominated by the Indian Premier League. This is an era in which West Indies are losing key players to the IPL due to financial incentives. Samuels' grueling effort in the second Test shows that Test cricket remains a challenging and rewarding experience. With the right approach, West Indies can build a strong foundation for future success.

at around 9.30am on Saturday. He said he pulled Scott's Mercedes over as a routine traffic stop for a broken brake light. He said Scott then ran away into a vacant grassy lot where, at some point during the chase, the victim confronts Slager. The officer then tried to use his Taser to subdue Scott, but claims the suspect grabbed the stun gun during the struggle, according to the statement. According to police reports, Slager fired the stun gun, but it did not stop Scott. At that point, the officer fired at Scott several times because he 'felt threatened,' Slager's statement said. Police then said Slager reported on his radio moments after the struggle: 'Shots fired and the subject is down. He took my Taser.' His department said the officers then performed CPR and delivered first aid to the victim. WHAT THE VIDEO SHOWS. Slager's account has been called into question after the video appears to show him shooting Scott in the back. The footage begins in the vacant lot apparently moments after Slager fires his Taser. Wires which administer the electrical current appear to be extending from Scott's body. As Scott turns to run, Slager draws his pistol and, only when he is 15 to 20 feet away, starts to fire the first of the eight shots at his back. The video shows Slager handcuffing Scott's lifeless body. Footage then appears to show Slager jogging back to the point where the Taser fell to the ground, bringing it over to Scott's body around 30 feet away and dropping it next to him. It is only after two-and-a-half minutes that Slager is seen placing his hand on Scott's neck in an apparent attempt to check his pulse. A black colleague then arrives and puts on blue medical gloves before handling the body, but is not seen performing first aid. They are joined by a third officer, who also does not appear to tend to the victim. The report is signed off by Sergeant James Gann. He states: 'I arrived on scene and observed that Officer Haberdasham was administering first aid to the driver. I exited my vehicle and assisted Officer Haberdasham with first aid and CPR to the driver.' He says they continued to give CPR until EMS arrived and Scott was pronounced dead. There is no evidence in Feidin Santana's video that Scott received CPR. A second video of the scene shows two other police officers arriving at the scene and getting out a medical kit.

Nina Moric, a 38-year-old model, denied claims that she tried to take her own life after collapsing in a domestic accident in Milan. She posted several photographs of her injuries on Instagram, which showed heavy bruising on her arms, and stated that she was treated in hospital and recovering at home. Her boyfriend, Luigi Mario Favoloso, suggested that she had attempted suicide, but Moric disputed this claim, saying she was simply trying to treat a medical issue.

Juventus secured a 0-0 draw against Monaco in their Champions League quarter-final match, progressing 1-0 on aggregate despite a gritty performance from the French side. Patrice Evra praised the Italian team's "ugly" style of play, which allowed them to secure their spot in the semi-finals. The win marked Juventus' first Champions League semi-final appearance since 2002-03. Evra also commended Monaco's Geoffrey Kondogbia for preventing Yannick Ferreira Carrasco from delivering a cross at the Stade Louis II. Despite Monaco's disappointment, Evra expressed confidence in the French team's ability to adapt and improve their defensive tactics.

A gorilla at Omaha's Henry Doorley Zoo threw its weight at a little girl, causing the glass to crack when it hit. The incident occurred during a family visit, but the gorilla's friend intervened, stopping the attack. The gorilla then launched itself at the child, hitting the glass with significant force, leading to the cracking of multiple panes. The family fled in fear, and the incident was caught on camera, resulting in over 126,000 views on YouTube.

John Suchet, a British actor, lost his wife Bonnie in 2015 after a decade-long battle with dementia. Their relationship was "made in heaven" according to him. He wrote a book and became honorary president of the Dementia UK charity after caring for his wife alone for three years. Now 71, Suchet is still grieving and has recently started dating again, describing his wife as "the love of his life".

Ben and Shelby Offrink met in college and started a study group together, where Ben would tell the others not to attend, allowing him to focus on Shelby. When Shelby was diagnosed with a rare type of brain cancer called an intramedullary glioblastoma, Ben helped her nickname the tumors and decided to "terminate" them. Despite facing a second diagnosis of Hodgkin's lymphoma, which recurred after being previously treated, Ben continues to fight and is now seeking new treatments, including a clinical trial with a promising drug. His wife Shelby's prognosis is six months, and their efforts are focused on finding alternative treatments and improving access to advanced cancer care in Michigan.

Real Madrid coach Carlo Ancelotti faces a difficult decision when selecting his starting lineup, as his team's attacking prowess hasn't been firing at the same level as usual. With several key players, including James Rodriguez, Isco, and Karim Benzema, all available, Ancelotti must choose between them to finalize his best starting XI. This is particularly challenging given the recent success of the "BBC" trio, who have combined to score 17 goals and provide 16 assists in their last three matches. The situation is further complicated by the departure of Isco, who was hit nine times by Granada at the weekend, but still remains a crucial part of Ancelotti's attack.

Floyd Mayweather will face off against Manny Pacquiao in the Fight of the Century at the MGM Grand in four days' time. He met fellow boxer Pacquiao on May 2 in Las Vegas, where tickets sold out within 60 seconds on Ticketmaster. Mayweather also posed for a photo with Motown legend Gladys Knight during a training session. The two fighters have been preparing for their highly anticipated bout, which is expected to be one of the biggest events in boxing history, with Mayweather reportedly earning £120 million from the fight.

Ed Miliband has hired a leadership coaching firm called ExtendedMind, which claims to help politicians improve their communication skills through neuroscience and business psychology. The firm's services include building "leadership skills" and helping politicians overcome anxiety and find their "inner voice". The firm's CEO, a US guru, advises politicians to focus on the "how" of their style rather than just their "artifice", suggesting that authenticity is key to effective communication. The firm's website emphasizes the importance of self-awareness and identifying potential collaborators to achieve goals.

A married limousine company manager, Raymond Townsends, was found liable for sexual harassment against his dispatcher, Geralyn Ganci, after sending her explicit texts and making unwanted advances. Ganci, who worked for US Limousine on Long Island, New York, reported being harassed by Townsend for over a year, including repeated requests for sex and lewd messages. In 2010, Ganci filed a lawsuit against Townsend, alleging that he fired her due to her refusal to engage in sexual activity. After a lengthy trial, a jury ruled in Ganci's favor, awarding her $5 million in damages. However, the case was later settled for $1.7 million, with Townsend and US Limousine also paying additional fees.

Bayern Munich playmaker Thiago made his return to action in a 1-0 win over Borussia Dortmund, playing for the first time in over a year. He came on as a substitute in the 1-0 victory at the Westfalenstadion. Thiago had missed three years without playing due to a serious knee injury, but praised the support of his teammates and fans. After watching the emotional reaction of the crowd, he revealed that football is indeed his life.

David Cameron accused the BBC of peddling 'b*******' after claiming his favourite sport was foxhunting, while also hitting back at presenter Andrew Marr over a previous statement he made on the show. Cameron's comments sparked a controversy when he appeared on the Andrew Marr Show and said he loved foxhunting, despite previously saying it was his favourite sport. Marr later admitted to making a mistake, stating that he had incorrectly stated this on Twitter.

Gwyneth Paltrow, a lifestyle guru, participated in the #FoodBankNYCChallenge, showcasing a week's worth of groceries for a person living on food stamps. She spent approximately $29 on leafy greens, dried beans, and rice, as part of the challenge. This is due to recent cuts to food stamps, which have led to increased demand at local soup kitchens and food pantries. Paltrow's participation aims to raise awareness about the challenges faced by those on food stamps.

Manchester United's Megastore, including its iconic mascot Fred the Red, is facing uncertainty due to a potential expiration of a £750m kit deal with Nike on July 31. Dozens of staff, including Fred, are sweating over their futures as they await confirmation on their employment status. The club's official mascot has been with the team since 1994 and is among those concerned about the impending change. Nike claims to be in constant communication with the club, but no agreement has been reached to end the deal early.

Liverpool edged past Blackburn Rovers 2-1 in their FA Cup sixth round replay to make it to a 24th Cup semi-final in the Anfield club's illustrious history. Philippe Coutinho eventually broke the deadlock after 161 goalless minutes across the two games, scoring in the 90+1 minute. Blackburn came close to levelling matters when goalkeeper Simon Eastwood was denied in stoppage time. The win keeps Liverpool's FA Cup hopes alive, while Blackburn's defeat marks a disappointing end to their campaign.

A heartwarming video shows six blindfolded children trying to identify their mothers by touch and scent, with the goal of understanding the special bond between mother and child. The video, called "The Unique Connection," features six women who are blindfolded and asked to pick out their child from a group of six others. The mothers' reactions range from anxiety to joy as they await the results. The video aims to celebrate Mother's Day and the unique connection between mothers and children.

Salford assistant coach Ian Watson is poised to come out of his playing retirement at 38 to answer an SOS from the Red Devils. His last game was as player-coach in the Championship for Swinton, where he stepped up his training ahead of Sunday's home game against Castleford. Salford are without several key players due to suspension and injury, including Rangi Chase, Weller Hauraki, and Darrell Griffin. If Watson plays, he would become the oldest player currently in Super League, surpassing the record held by Australian Steve Menzies, who turned 39 in 2013.

Jordan Spieth took the first-day honors at the 79th Masters with a stunning opening round of 64, becoming the youngest first-round leader in Masters history. He shared the lead with 34-year-old Justin Rose and 45-year-old Ernie Els, posting six birdies in seven holes before adding a flourish at the 18th. Spieth's incredible run included a birdie on the 18th, where he successfully sunk a 25-foot putt to take a three-shot lead into the second round. Most favored players, including Rory McIlroy and defending champion Bubba Watson, struggled to find their footing, with McIlroy appearing relaxed and Watson struggling to find his rhythm.

Alastair Cook must somehow shut out the deafening noise enveloping English cricket and concentrate on what has become one of the most important Test series of his career. Defeat against West Indies in a three-Test battle that begins here on Monday is simply unthinkable for an England captain who is desperate to avoid being distracted by the seismic changes going on all around him. Alastair Cook's focus is on avoiding distractions amidst the chaos caused by the departure of Paul Downton, speculation about Kevin Pietersen, and the appointment of a new director of cricket. Despite struggling to cope with these pressures, Cook has shown resilience in recent performances, including a three-hundred run-scoring average in his last four Test matches. With the imminent first Test against West Indies, Cook must navigate the challenges ahead and ensure a successful series.

The Pentagon plans to exhume and try to identify the remains of nearly 400 sailors and Marines killed when the USS Oklahoma sank in the bombing of Pearl Harbor in 1941. Altogether, 429 sailors and Marines were killed, with only 35 identified in the years immediately after the attack. The military is acting nearly 75 years after the incident due to advances in forensic science and technology, as well as genealogical help from family members. The goal is to identify up to 388 servicemen within five years, with the remaining unidentified remains to be buried in a new cemetery.

A YouTube video featuring Yousef Saleh Erakat, a comedian and entertainer, shows him disguising himself as a homeless man to test whether offering money to those in need is more or less kind. The experiment reveals that many people respond with anger and hostility when offered money, rather than kindness.

A 18-year-old college student, Anjelica "AJ" Hadsell, disappeared while on spring break in Norfolk, Virginia, leaving her family desperate for answers. Her mother, Katherine Hadsell, is seeking more insight from police into what they're doing to find her daughter, who has been missing for a month. Her stepfather, Wesley Hadsell, was arrested for breaking into a Norfolk-area home, claiming he acted out of concern for his daughter's safety. Police are searching a pond near Carrsville, Virginia, in an effort to locate AJ's cell phone, which was found with her jacket.

Australian researchers have developed a drone called Joggobot that can be used as a jogging companion, tracking the speed and direction of the user through a pattern on their shirt. The drone follows a set path and provides encouragement, helping users maintain a consistent pace. The technology has been tested with 13 joggers, who reported feeling motivated and supported by the drone. While there were some concerns about safety and camera placement, the results suggest that the drone could be a useful tool for jogging and other physical activities.

A man in New Zealand has quit his well-paying job as an agricultural adviser to become a mechanic due to a $600-a-month increase in child support payments, which reduced his monthly payment from $1,900 to $554. This change was made by Inland Revenue, which updated its child support formula on April 1. The change affects parents who were expecting to pay around $70,000 per year in child support. To avoid this increase, one parent reported giving up a significant portion of their income, such as $70,000 per year, for a lower wage of $38,000 per year.

A British man, Navinder Singh Sarao, has been accused of causing the 2010 "flash crash" by making illicit trades back in 2009. US authorities suspect he used special computer software to manipulate the market on Wall Street, triggering a $850 billion wipe from global share prices in just five minutes. Sarao allegedly made £26 million from these trades over five years, and was investigated by six agencies in both the US and Britain before being charged with criminal offenses. An investigation team involved in the case wants Sarao put on trial in New York.

Canadian expat Lisa Webb first sent her vegetable-phobic three-year-old to school in France in 2009, fearing she would starve due to the unfamiliar menu. However, upon visiting the school, she discovered that the children were eating a variety of dishes, including rôti de boeuf and cordon bleu de dinde, which she found shocking. Lisa eventually became a substitute teacher in Paris and started taking her daughter to the school's canteen for lunch, where she observed the children eating a three-course meal at the table, rather than a buffet-style meal.

A survey found that 64% of adults who shop with friends tend to spend more money than they would if they shopped alone, citing "showing off" as a primary reason. This phenomenon is often referred to as the "social spending trap." Many participants reported feeling pressured by friends to make impulse purchases, such as buying clothes, shoes, and entertainment items. Despite giving themselves a budget before shopping, 95% of respondents admitted to overspending, with top categories being food, clothing, household items, shoes, and entertainment.

Phillip Schofield was left speechless after a guest with Tourette's syndrome blurted out'silver fox' at him during an appearance on ITV's This Morning. Ellie Grant, 22, appeared on the show discussing how she developed Tourette's syndrome at age 21 and found love with deaf fiancé Jordan, who switches off his hearing aid when she has a series of loud tics. The couple met and fell in love despite her initial fear of finding someone who could tolerate her outbursts. Phillip Schofield was left speechless after the guest blurted out'silver fox' at him during the interview.

Adam Gadahn, a 36-year-old US citizen and al Qaeda operative, was killed in a US government counterterrorism operation in January. Neither he nor another US citizen, Ahmed Farouq, was specifically targeted, but rather in a separate operation. Gadahn converted to Islam in 1995 and rose through the ranks of al Qaeda in Pakistan, becoming its chief English-language propagandist. He was indicted in 2006 for treason and material support to al Qaeda, and appeared in several videos criticizing US policies and targeting specific individuals, including President George W. Bush and US Ambassador Chris Stevens.

Formula One driver Jenson Button completed the London Marathon with an impressive time of two hours, 52 minutes and 30 seconds. The 35-year-old McLaren driver finished behind former Olympic rower James Cracknell, who also ran for Cancer Research. Button praised the "amazing atmosphere" and collective spirit of the runners. Button was running on behalf of the charity, describing his experience as "really really emotional".
